Review Advances and insights in amorphous electrocatalyst towards water splitting Xiaohan Wang a Han Tian b * Xu Yu b Lisong Chen c Xiangzhi Cui a b * Jianlin Shi b a School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hangzhou Institute for Advanced Study, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hangzhou 310024, Zhejiang, China School of Chemistry and Materials Science Hangzhou Institute for Advanced Study University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Hangzhou Zhejiang 310024 China School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hangzhou Institute for Advanced Study, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hangzhou 310024, Zhejiang, China b State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200050, China State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure Shanghai Institute of Ceramics Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 200050 China State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200050, China c Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200062, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering East China Normal University Shanghai 200062 China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200062, China * Corresponding author. Amorphous materials can markedly enhance the active site amount and optimize the adsorption and desorption of reactants owing to the special structural characteristics of large numbers of randomly oriented bonds and surface-exposed defects. Therefore, many amorphous electrocatalysts have emerged for effectively catalyzing water splitting. Considering the advancement of novel in-situ techniques and theoretical density functional theory calculations, significant progress emerging in amorphous electrocatalysts for water splitting needs to be summarized urgently. Herein, the recent progress of amorphous catalyst materials in water splitting has been systematically reviewed, emphasizing key issues of synthesis methods, stabilization strategies, performance evaluation, mechanistic understanding, integrated experiments, and theoretical studies in water splitting, including hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, and overall water splitting. This study focuses on these topics to present the most updated results and the perspectives and challenges for the future development of amorphous electrocatalysts toward water splitting. Graphical Abstract A detailed summary of amorphous electrocatalysts towards water splitting including synthesis methods, stabilization strategies, performance evaluation, and mechanistic understanding is reviewed, and the most up-to-date results are presented, along with the perspectives and challenges for the future development of amorphous electrocatalysts. Keywords Amorphous catalyst Defect engineering Water splitting Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction Fossil fuels shortage and the accompanying environmental pollution have triggered significant interest in finding sustainable, clean, and highly efficient energy sources to satisfy the existing energy need [ 1,2 ]. Hydrogen (H2), an important energy carrier, is a potential alternative to fossil fuel because of its high energy density and clean combustion products [ 3 ]. Of all the ways to produce hydrogen [ 4,5 ], the electrolysis of water is an efficient and clean technology for obtaining high-purity hydrogen [ 6 ], which includes two half-cell reactions: hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the cathode and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode [ 3,7–10 ]. To conduct electrochemical water splitting, highly efficient electrocatalysts in HER and OER are needed to overcome the thermodynamic barriers [ 11,12 ]. The most widely used HER and OER catalysts until now are Pt-group metals and RuO2/IrO2, respectively [ 13,14 ]. However, the high cost and scarcity of these noble metals [ 15 ] seriously limit their widespread utilization in water‐splitting electrolyzers [ 16 ]. Furthermore, rutile-type RuO2 and IrO2 are highly unstable and readily dissolve in acidic and alkaline electrolytes under high anodic potential [ 17 ]. Driven by these challenges, an enormous amount of research efforts for developing low-cost electrocatalysts (e.g., making alloys [ 18–21 ] or controlling the morphology and size of electrocatalysts) [ 22–26 ] have been reported recently to improve the efficiency of hydrogen production from electrolytic water, including hydroxides, oxides, phosphates, metals, alloys, carbides, borides, nitrides, sulfides, etc. [ 27,28 ]. However, developing highly efficient and cost-economical water splitting electrocatalysts to improve electrolytic efficiency and minimize energy consumption due to hydrogen production is still a challenge [ 29,30 ]. The main methods for improving the catalytic activity of electrocatalysts can be divided into two: (1) the more active sites on a given electrode and (2) the more robust intrinsic activity of each active site [ 31 ]. Amorphous materials possess many randomly oriented bonds and surface-exposed defects, which can markedly enhance the active site amount and optimize the adsorption and desorption of reactants [ 32 ]. After Klement first performed the classic rapid-quenching experiments on Au-Si alloys in 1960 [ 33 ], amorphous materials were not used for water splitting until the late 1980s and early 1990s [ 34–37 ]. Since then, many amorphous electrocatalysts have emerged for effectively catalyzing HER, OER, and overall water splitting (OWS). Compared with crystals, amorphous materials do not have a strict crystal structure. Although the formation of amorphous structures creates a large number of defects and, thus, more active sites for efficient water splitting [ 38 ], the numerous dangling bonds and abundant unsaturated surface atoms created by the amorphous phase also provide a lot of adsorption sites for reactants. Therefore, as promising OWS electrocatalysts, amorphous materials usually have higher catalytic activity and associated properties such as low hardness, large surface area, and chemical stability [ 39,40 ]. Although some researchers have also summarized the applications of amorphous electrocatalysis materials toward HER, OER, ORR, and CO2RR, a more comprehensive review is needed [ 41–44 ]. With the development of in-situ techniques and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the progress in using amorphous electrocatalysts for water splitting has increased significantly. Herein, we comprehensively and systematically review the latest developments of amorphous electro-catalysts in water splitting, including HER, OER, and OWS applications. Firstly, we summarize the electrochemical mechanisms for water splitting under alkaline and acidic media, including the underlying HER and OER mechanisms. Then, the synthesis methods of amorphous materials and the stability mechanism are intensively discussed. Afterward, as shown in Fig. 1 , the amorphous electro-catalysts in water splitting are intensively discussed. Specifically, the architecture is categorized into precious and nonprecious composites in three kinds of electrochemical reactions (HER, OER, and OWS). Lastly, we conclude with a perspective on research challenges and development directions of amorphous electro-catalysts in water-splitting applications. 2 Mechanisms of water splitting In general, the electrochemical reactions of water splitting comprise two half-reactions, which facilitate HER at the cathode and OER at the anode in acidic and alkaline media, and are given as follows [ 45 ]: In acidic media: 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2 E = 0.00 V (vs. SHE) 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e− E = 1.23 V (vs. SHE) In alkaline media: 4H2O + 4e− → 2H2 + 4OH− E = –0.83 V (vs. SHE) 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e− E = 0.40 V (vs. SHE) According to a plot of pH against the standard electrochemical potential, a thermodynamic potential of 1.23 V is required to drive electrochemical water splitting under standard conditions, corresponding to an energy input of ΔG = 237.1 kJ mol−1 [ 46 ]. Unfortunately, the sluggish kinetics of both HER and OER and the inevitable energy loss require a higher overpotential to reach appreciable current density, resulting in the input potential of water splitting in a practical electrolyzer much larger than 1.23 V [ 45 ]. Thus, reducing energy loss and improving energy conversion efficiency in electrochemical water splitting is necessary. This can be achieved by designing high-performance electrocatalysts that would deliver high current densities even with small catalyst loadings. Understanding the mechanisms of HER and OER further contributes to the design of high-performance electrocatalysts [ 42 ]. 2.1 HER mechanism Mechanistically, three possible principal steps are involved in the electrochemical HER process for the reduction of protons in acidic media (Fig. 2 left) or water molecules in alkaline media (Fig. 2 right) to hydrogen molecules (H2) on the surface of an electrode with a minimum external potential applied [ 47 ]. The overall HER can be written as follows: In acidic media: (1) Volmer reaction: H+ + e− → H* (2) Tafel reaction: H* + H* → H2 (3) Heyrovsky reaction: H+ + H * + e− → H2 In alkaline media: (4) Volmer reaction: H2O + e− → H* + OH− (5) Tafel reaction: H* + H* → H2 (6) Heyrovsky Reaction: H2O + e− + H* → H2 + OH− The first step is the Volmer reaction (Eqs. (1) and (4)), where a proton or H2O molecule reacts with an electron to generate an adsorbed hydrogen atom (H*) on the electrode material surface. The proton sources are the hydronium cation (H3O+) and water molecules in acidic and alkaline electrolytes, respectively. Subsequently, the H2 formation may occur via the Heyrovsky reaction (Eqs. (3) and (6)) or the Tafel reaction (Eqs. (2) and (5)) or both. In the Heyrovsky step, another proton diffuses to the H* and then reacts with a second electron to produce H2. In the Tafel step, two H* in the vicinity combine on the surface of the electrode to evolve H2 [ 48 ]. In the HER process, the binding force between the catalyst and catalytic intermediates should be in a suitable state, as too strong or too weak binding force will hinder the water splitting. To understand the composition-structure-function relationship, a volcano plot of the affinity of catalysts for reaction intermediates has been proposed, and its intuitive concept is beneficial for researchers to understand the reaction kinetics of catalysts. At equilibrium potential, the free energy of adsorbed hydrogen in solution should be close to zero. The volcano curves in alkaline and acidic environments are similar, and the catalysts containing Pt, Pd, and Ir show theoretically superior HER performance (Figs. 3(a) and 3(b) ) [ 49 ]. In conclusion, the volcano plot is an effective way to visualize the catalytic reactions, which are usually based on the adsorption energy of a single intermediate. However, the kinetics of the electrochemical reaction is actually a complex process. 2.2 OER mechanism OER is a reaction that produces oxygen by four-electron transfer, and the OER mechanism varies somewhat as the acid-base medium changes. Theoretically, the thermodynamic equilibrium potential of an OER is 1.23 V (vs. RHE), and the applied potential is much higher than the theoretical equilibrium potential due to the generation of reaction energy barriers during the actual electrolysis. In recent years, the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) and lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) have been proposed by studying catalytic reaction processes. 2.2.1 AEM AEM assumes that the OER process consists of four proton-electron transfer steps, as shown in Fig. 4 , during which the generation and conversion of *OH, *O, *OOH occur mainly, and there is a scalar relationship between the adsorption energies of these oxygen-containing intermediates. In acidic media: (7) * + H2O → *OH + e− + H+ (8) *OH → *O + e− + H+ (9) *O + H2O → *OOH + e− + H+ (10) *OOH → O2 + * + e− + H+ In alkaline media: (11) OH− → *OH + e− (12) *OH + OH− → *O + e− + H2O (13) *O + OH− → *OOH + e− (14) *OOH + OH− → O2 + * + e− + H2O Under acidic conditions (Fig. 4(a) left), water molecules are first adsorbed on the catalytic active site and form *OH through a deprotonation process (Eq. (7)). Then, the *OH species are further dehydrogenated and oxidized to form *O (Eq. (8)), and a second water molecule deprotonates on the *O species to form the intermediate product of *OOH (Eq. (9)). Finally, *OOH undergoes a deprotonation process and desorbs to form oxygen molecules (Eq. (10)). In alkaline environment (Fig. 4(a) right), the first step of reaction that occurs on the electrode surface is OH− adsorption and loss of one electron to form *OH adsorbed species (Eq. (11)), followed by *OH formation on the electrode by deprotonation to form *O and *OOH (Eqs. (12) and (13)). Finally, *OOH discharges with another OH− and releases oxygen molecules (Eq. (14)). 2.2.2 LOM The lattice oxygen of the catalyst is involved in the catalytic reaction during the LOM process, as shown in Fig. 4. Under acidic conditions (Fig. 4(b) left), H2O is first adsorbed on the catalytic center of the monometallic site and discharged, followed by the removal of protons and electrons to form *O species. The *O species is directly coupled to the active lattice oxygen through surface reconstruction to generate O2, and OH- is replenished and regenerated as H2O is adsorbed on the active center again. After the deprotonation step, the metal ion returns to its starting valence state and adsorbs the next H2O to continue the OER. Under alkaline conditions (Fig. 4(b) right), the LOM pathway is similar to the acidic LOM pathway, except that the adsorbed hydrogen-oxygen species originates from OH−. The energy difference of the intermediates Oads and OHads s is used to evaluate the OER activity of the catalysts. There are three oxygen-containing intermediates (*OOH, *O, and *OH) in the conventional AEM process, and they all adsorb on the surface via O atoms. The binding energies of *OOH (E HOO*), *O (E O*), and *OH (E HO*) are linearly correlated, which is commonly seen on metal and metal oxide surfaces (Fig. 5(a) ). When the bonding of adsorbed oxygen on the active site is significantly stronger or weaker, the potential is limited by the formation of *OOH and *OH species, respectively, leading to a volcano relationship between the catalytic activity and oxygen adsorption energy. The rational use of the volcano plot can facilitate the design of catalysts with excellent performance by reducing ΔGO*-ΔGHO* near the top of the volcano plot (Fig. 5(b)) [ 50 ]. 3 The fundamentals of amorphous electrocatalysts Crystalline materials are solids with the feature of long-range ordering in which the internal atoms are arranged periodically and repeatedly in a three-dimensional space. Owing to their low internal energy and good stability, crystalline materials can spontaneously grow into regular geometric polyhedral structures with fixed melting points. In contrast, amorphous materials are solids whose internal atoms are arranged following the rule of short-range order and long-range disorder, which do not have a fixed melting point. Generally, amorphous materials can be spontaneously transformed into crystalline materials owing to their higher internal energy and less stability than their counterpart. Conversely, crystalline materials can also be transformed into amorphous states after the disruption of the regular arrangement of internal atoms. Owing to the synergy of a large number of defects and the dangling bonds in the amorphous structure, amorphous catalysts can expose more active sites, which are usually more active than crystalline ones. Moreover, the disordered atom arrangement in amorphous catalysts is anisotropic, which can effectively inhibit material corrosion because of the difficulty of atom diffusion into the interior. Unfortunately, the metastable and flexible structure of the amorphous catalysts makes it difficult to synthesize and maintain the electrochemical stability. Recently, some effective strategies and design rules have been developed in which the microscopic morphology of amorphous catalysts can be easily tuned along with excellent stability in long-term electrochemical testing. By combining quantum mechanics, thermodynamics, kinetics, simulations, and reliable experimental data, high-throughput computation can build up a database of chemical components, crystal/molecular structures, etc., and explore the relationship between material structure and properties. Combining density functional theory and high-throughput material design may predict the performance of amorphous materials, which can accelerate the development and application of amorphous catalysts in the future (Fig. 6 ). 4 Synthesis of amorphous catalyst materials 4.1 Synthesis methods In addition to the direct synthesis of amorphous catalysts, the amorphous conversions of crystals are generally classified into physical and chemical methods (Table 1 ). The physical method breaks the lattice of long-range order by pressure, mechanical force, heat, irradiation, etc. Pressure and mechanical forces are applied to the catalyst by high pressure and ball milling, causing the collapse of the crystal structure and producing an amorphous state. Irradiation sources (including X-rays and microwaves) produce photo-oxidation and microwave-induced thermal stirring to promote amorphization. With simple processing and controlled changes, chemical methods convert crystals to amorphous structures by doping, insertion, reduction, electrochemical conversion, surface modification, and ion exchange. Several commonly used methods for the preparation of amorphous alloys are listed below. 4.1.1 Plunge cooling method Very high cooling rates have been shown to preserve the short-range ordered and long-range disordered structural characteristics of amorphous alloys. By cooling the molten metal or alloy at a rate of 105–106 K s−1, the atoms are solidified in the solute before they can be regularly aligned. Zhang et al. [ 51–55 ] sputtered molten high-purity iron, cobalt, phosphorus, and carbon onto a rotating copper roller, which rotated at a high speed and a cooling rate of 105–106 K s−1 to obtain amorphous alloy strips, and then obtained amorphous Fe40Co40P13C7 master alloy. The composition of the amorphous catalysts prepared by the plunge cooling method can be varied in a wide range, and the obtained catalysts are uniform in composition and structure, which is conducive to the adjustment of the electronic structure and the uniform distribution of active centers. However, the thermal stability of the prepared amorphous catalysts is poor, and the specific area is small. In addition, the initial catalytic activity of the amorphous catalysts prepared using the plunge cooling method is low, which requires activation in acidic, alkaline solutions or special atmospheres. During the activation process, the oxides on the catalyst surface are reduced, and the specific surface area increases, resulting in a significant increase in catalytic activity [ 56 ]. 4.1.2 Chemical reduction method To resolve the problem of small specific surface area of amorphous catalysts obtained by plunge cooling method, the chemical reduction method is developed to obtain amorphous catalysts with a high specific surface area [ 57 ]. Chemical reduction is an effective method to prepare amorphous alloy catalysts with a high specific area by reducing metal ions with reducing agents (e.g., hypophosphites and borohydrides) at room temperature. [ 58–60 ] Under nitrogen protection and mechanical stirring, Tang et al. added sodium borohydride to an aqueous solution containing metal salts and sodium hypophosphite, washed and dried the solution to prepare Ni-Fe-P-B amorphous compound, which displays excellent catalytic activity toward overall water splitting (Page 7, line 3). Li et al. [ 61 ] mixed an aqueous solution of PdCuCo alloy with Ni(NO3)2 and added sodium borohydride solution after ultrasonic treatment to prepare amorphous nickel borohydride film-coated PdCuCo after washing and centrifuging the solution. The amorphous alloy catalysts prepared by the chemical reduction method do not need activation treatment before use and show 50–100 times higher catalytic activity than those prepared by the plunge cooling method. Unfortunately, however, the catalysts are easily deactivated by oxidation in air [ 61 ]. 4.1.3 Chemical reduction loading method By impregnating Ni and other metal salts on the porous carrier and then contacting with reducing agents, the active component can be uniformly reduced on the surface of the catalyst carrier, avoiding the problems of poor thermal stability, non-uniformity of the active component, and high cost of the catalyst prepared by the chemical reduction method. Tong et al. [ 83 ] mixed aqueous solutions of EO20PO70EO20 (P123) with different mass percentage concentrations and added cobalt acetate, mixed well for 8 h and then added aqueous potassium borohydride solution. After washing and refluxing at high temperatures, the mesoporous Co-B amorphous alloy catalyst was prepared. In addition, Jiang et al. [ 84 ] dissolved the block polymer PS-b-PEO in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), followed by the addition of cobalt acetate and aqueous dimethylamine-borane, and then added inert gas Ar to protect the metallic cobalt after removing dissolved oxygen from the solution. Finally, the mesoporous amorphous cobalt boron (a-CoB x ) alloy colloidal particles were prepared after adding the NaBH4 as reducer (Figs. 7(a)–(h) ). By choosing different carriers, the specific surface area and pore structure of the amorphous catalysts can be effectively adjusted by the loading method. 4.1.4 Vapor phase deposition method Most of the above-mentioned preparation methods are used to obtain amorphous alloys, and then the vapor deposition can obtain amorphous pure metals (Fe, Ni, Co, etc.), which works by heating the metal in a vacuum or inert environment and then depositing vaporized molecules or atoms on the substrate. Amorphous pure metal or amorphous alloy with small film thickness can be successfully obtained using the vapor phase deposition method by heating the metal under a vacuum or inert environment and then depositing the vaporized molecules or atoms on the substrate. The vapor phase deposition method can be divided into electrical discharge machining (EDM), ion sputtering, vacuum coating, and glow discharge methods. The EDM method utilizes a very high cooling rate (109 K s−1) to prepare amorphous alloys. At room temperature, the alloy is prepared as an electrode and inserted into an insulating liquid. A high voltage will be passed between the two electrodes, and when the electric field strength is greater than the dielectric strength of the dielectric, the electrons emitted from the cathode collide rapidly with the neutral atoms of the anode, forming a high-temperature ion channel to vaporize the alloy, followed by rapid cooling and quenching in the liquid to form amorphous superfine particles. Guo et al. [ 85 ] fixed the silver electrode in a conductive iron container connected to the EDM machine. Then, the coolant is poured, and the distance between the two electrodes is adjusted. When an electric spark is generated, the silver becomes silver vapor or silver droplets at a high temperature and cools rapidly to form amorphous silver nanoparticles after meeting water. The ion sputtering method is commonly used for preparing amorphous rare earth metal films. However, the substrate warms up rapidly during preparation, which affects the film generation. Vacuum coating and glow discharge methods are similar to ion sputtering, but the thickness of the formed amorphous films is small, and the corresponding uniformity is poor. So, they can only be used to prepare some special amorphous alloy catalysts. 4.1.5 Other preparation methods In addition, amorphous alloy materials such as nano-chain-like, nano-tubular, and nano-films have been successfully prepared [ 86–88 ]. Core-shell structure and one-, two-, and three-dimensional amorphous alloy materials exhibit properties different from those of bulk-phase amorphous alloys because of their special structures, and the controlled synthesis and property studies of the materials are attractive (Fig. 8 ). Liao et al. [ 87 ] prepared amorphous TiO2 nanotube array film by anodic oxidation of titanium flakes in a fluorinated electrolyte. In another piece of work, Chen et al. [ 88 ] immersed SBA-15 in KBH4 and added an aqueous nickel citrate solution, then sonicated again until no air bubbles were released. After the silica template was removed with sodium hydroxide, the Ni-B amorphous alloy nanoarray was prepared by washing and centrifugation. In addition, Kim et al. [ 89 ] prepared CNT-amorphous FePO4 core-shell nanowires by immersing CNT in a mixture of sulfuric acid and nitric acid, rinsing it with deionized water after sonication, and then the entire CNT surface was covered with FePO4 after ion adsorption and mineralization, and subsequently annealing it at high temperature after filtration. 4.2 Stability strategy Amorphous catalysts can undergo surface rearrangement to adapt HER/OER due to the absence of grain boundaries and dislocations. Generally, amorphous catalysts should be more stable and corrosion-resistant than their crystalline counterparts, while in the electrochemical process, the active sites in amorphous catalysts are easily attacked by water or to form chemical bonds with ions, leading to unsatisfactory long-term stability. Since chemical and electrochemical corrosion often occurs during OER/HER, the performance of amorphous catalysts decreases sharply at high current densities. Thus, it is important to increase the stability of amorphous catalysts. Several methods for improving the stability of amorphous materials are described below. 4.2.1 Self-healing For lots of alloys [ 90,91 ], oxides [ 92 ], and hydroxides [ 93 ], the materials have a self-healing process and an in-situ phase transition after conversion to the amorphous state. The stability has already been enhanced after being induced into the amorphous state [ 94–96 ]. Yang et al. [ 97 ] prepared unique multi-block terpolymers with a half-sandwich scandium catalyst. The microphase separation between the crystalline and non-crystalline segments enhances the elasticity and self-healing ability of the polymer. The glass transition temperature of the polymer increases linearly with increasing ANaphP content in the material (Fig. 9(a) and Table 2 ), and the ratio of AHexP/ANaphP changed the mechanical properties of the material. P3 (AHexP/ANaphP/E = 11/28/61) behaves as a flexible plastic at room temperature due to the higher ANaphP content (Fig. 9(b)), and P4 (AHexP/ANaphP/E = 19/17/64) and P1 (AHexP/ANaphP/E = 21/19/60) exhibit a remarkable rate of self-healing in addition to good elasticity (Figs. 9(c) and 9(d)). P1 was cut at room temperature and then closed, and the test revealed that P1 recovered 90% of its tensile strength within 1 h [ 97 ]. 4.2.2 Formation of passivation film The formation of passivation films on amorphous catalysts is facilitated by the addition of Cr, Mo, and W to enhance the stability. In addition, the partially amorphous structure of these alloys can mitigate the adverse effects of microstructural non-uniformity and improve the corrosion resistance of the catalysts. Bott et al. compared Fe-based amorphous alloys doped with different elements and tested the corrosion resistance of the materials via over-corrosion potential measurements and potentiodynamic polarization methods. It was found that the Cr-containing alloy (FeCrNiB-type alloy) formed a stable passivation film during the reaction, which enhanced the stability of the amorphous alloy [ 98 ]. Kiminami et al. [ 99 ] compared four Mo- or Nb-containing amorphous Fe-Cr-based alloys for their corrosion resistance, thermal stability, and the effect of their partial crystallization. The crystallization temperature increased with the addition of Nb or Mo, indicating that these elements stabilized the amorphous phase and small amounts of Nb and/or Mo (0.6 wt%) were sufficient to increase the corrosion resistance of the FeCr-based amorphous alloys. Nb and Mo had a synergistic effect in strengthening the overall corrosion resistance, which can greatly enhance the corrosion resistance of the alloys [ 99 ]. 4.2.3 Addition of rare earth elements Rare earth elements, especially heavy rare earth elements, can significantly improve the thermodynamic parameters of amorphous alloys, such as glass transition temperature (T g), initial crystallization temperature (T x), peak crystallization temperature (T p), and reduced glass temperature (T rg), and effectively improve the stability when external temperature changes. The atomic radius of rare earth elements is larger than that of common metallic elements, and adding rare earth elements results in a larger difference in atomic size and a greater entropy. The reduction of eutectic temperature makes the crystal structure less likely to be formed [ 100 ]. Zhang et al. [ 101 ] explored the effect of rare earth elements on thermodynamic parameters by adjusting the addition ratio of yttrium in Zr55Al15Ni10Cu20 alloys. The subcooled liquid region (ΔT = Tx – T g) reached a maximum when the addition amount reached 2%, and the glass transition temperature (T rg) decreased to a maximum when the addition amount was 4%. The larger the ΔT and T rg, the easier it is to form the amorphous state and the lower the critical cooling rate [ 101 ]. In addition, Zhang et al. [ 102 ] added yttrium to Cu-Zr-Al amorphous alloy and found that the atomic level strain energy is closely related to the atomic stacking efficiency of the precipitated crystals, and a smaller amount of yttrium can suppress the precipitation of the crystalline phase. 5 Application of amorphous electrocatalyst in water splitting 5.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction 5.1.1 Precious metal based amorphous catalysts Among the alternative energy sources at this stage, hydrogen produced by HER has been highly valued for its future development. Currently, platinum-based materials are recognized as the most effective HER catalysts, while the high cost and low reserves of precious metals limit their wide application. Considering the activity enhancement of amorphous structures and lowering precious metal usage, amorphous materials have gradually been studied as effective substitute electrocatalysts toward HER. Guo and co-workers [ 103 ] managed to synthesize amorphous ruthenium phosphide (RuP x ) by reducing NaH2PO2 and RuCl3 with NaBH4 via a one-pot reaction at room temperature. Only 31 mV overpotential is required to reach 10 mA cm−2 in N2-saturated 1 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte, and no obvious decay in the HER process is observed after 24 h of catalysis at 100 mA cm−2. The chemical properties of Pd are similar to Pt. However, strong Pd-H bonds hinder the desorption of Hads, and the hydride phase makes the electrocatalyst less stable during the catalytic process. Bao et al. [ 63 ] constructed amorphous PdNi-S/C nanowires successfully through the hydrothermal synthesis method and employed them as HER catalysts. The result indicated that the amorphous PdNi-S/C catalyst manifests superb HER performance in alkaline electrolyte (1 mol L−1 KOH) with an overpotential of 67 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, a Tafel slope of 69.4 mV dec mol L−1, and considerable long-term durability. The one-dimensional nanowire structure, abundant sulfur vacancies and defects, and the synergistic effect between PdNi-S nanowires and the graphite carbon results in the outstanding alkaline HER performance for PdNi-S/C. The DFT computation results further prove that the construction of amorphous PdNi-S/C can speed up the adsorption of the H2O molecule, the cleavage of H–OH bonds, and the recombination of H*, explaining the promising performance of catalysts [ 63 ]. Yang et al. [ 104 ] produced a self-supporting three-dimensional interconnected nanoporous core/shell Ag-Pd hybrid with sub-nanometer amorphous platinum-rich skins (Pt-Pd@NPA) as the efficient pH-universal HER electrocatalyst by combining in-situ electrochemical galvanic replacement, potential cycling activation, and the alloying/dealloying process. The optimized Pt-Pd@NPA can deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with low overpotential of only 28.1, 34.8 and 23.8 mV and little Tafel slop of 31.2, 32.2, and 32.5 mV dec−1 in acidic (0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4), neutral (1 mol L−1 PBS), and alkaline (1 mol L−1 KOH) media, respectively (Figs. 10(a)–(c)). Impressively, this efficient catalyst with sub-nanometer amorphous platinum-rich skins can achieve a rather big current density of 1000 mA cm−2 steadily in an extremely acidic environment (0.5–7.0 mol L−1 H2SO4) (Figs. 10(d) and (e) ). To simplify the calculations, the authors used Pt and Pd to substitute for one atomic layer of Ag (111) slab to represent the catalyst models of Pd@NPA (Pd@Ag (111)), Pt@NPA (Pt@Ag (111)), and Pt-Pd@NPA (Pt-Pd@Ag (111)), respectively (Fig. 10(f)). Pt-Pd@NPA possesses the optimal ΔG H* (Fig. 10(h)), especially, the addition of Pt can decrease the ΔG H* of Pd@NPA from 0.09 eV to 0.03 eV (Fig. 10(g)), thus promoting the adsorption-desorption process [ 104 ]. Compared to its crystalline counterpart, amorphous MoS2 has a higher content of unsaturated sulfur atoms on the surface, which form active sites for the HER reaction, but it is less stable during the reaction. Xu et al. [ 62 ] synthesized amorphous triple Pd-Cu-S nanoporous substances produced by the sulfation treatment of Ti-Cu-Pd precursors after dealloying. The overpotential for HER with this amorphous triple Pd-Cu-S substance at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 is 58 mV, and the Tafel slope is 35 mV dec−1, which is very near to Pt-based catalysts. The efficient catalytic ability was ascribed to the material's bicontinuous constitution and the existence of a large quantity of bridging S2 2– and apical S2– species in the amorphous phase as well as electron redistribution between Pd and Cu, which weaken the hydrogen binding energy and thereby promoted the desorption rate of H species. Moreover, the amorphous triple Pd-Cu-S material also showed excellent electrochemical durability for HER even in 7 mol L−1 H2SO4 solution, indicating its great potential as an alternative cost-efficient non-Pt HER catalyst [ 62 ]. During electrochemical cycling, amorphous Pt can rapidly self-recon to improve HER performance. Ma et al. [ 105 ] crystallized and oxidized amorphous Pt (A-Pt) nanospheres to form Pt-O ligands by self-activation. The overpotential of A-Pt, which had undergone 50 chemical cycles, was significantly reduced from the initial 89.7 to 18.8 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. It was shown that the catalytic performance can be enhanced by optimizing the atomic structure of nanomaterials to effectively improve the utilization of precious metals. Surface strain is an effective means to modulate the electronic structure of catalysts, which can move the d-band center and regulate the adsorption and activation energy barriers of reaction intermediates. Wu et al. [ 106 ] constructed amorphous-crystalline phase boundaries by nanosheets, generating about 4% tensile strain. The strained Ir nanosheets (AC-Ir NSs) have excellent HER performance, corresponding to an overpotential of only 17 mV (vs. RHE) at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, superior to most catalysts reported (Table 3 ). Noble metals such as Pt and Ru are the most active and stable HER materials, and their catalytic performance can be improved by amorphization. However, their extremely high cost and limited reserves hinder their industrial application. Therefore, one of the future research goals for amorphous noble metal catalysts is to partially/completely replace Pt with low-cost and highly active catalytic materials. 5.1.2 Non-precious metal based amorphous catalysts 5.1.2.1 Amorphous iron based electrocatalysts Iron, which is cheap, less toxic, and abundant in the earth exhibits prospective potential application in electrode materials. Compared with other electrodes, iron-based materials are usually corroded more seriously during the whole operation process, thus facing the problem of long-term stability. An effective way to adjust the catalytic efficiency of amorphous Fe-based materials is to change the metal composition by different elements [ 118–120 ]. Li et al. [ 121 ] applied colloidal chemistry to design amorphous iron and cobalt-based phosphate catalysts using nickel foam support for the non-precious Fe-based amorphous catalysts. The introduction of iron can activate the charge transfer efficiency of Co. Thus, the obtained Fe0.72Co0.42PO4/Ni catalyst possesses an ultra-low overpotential of 77 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, excellent mechanical robustness and durability [ 121 ]. Wang et al. [ 122 ] prepared Ni-Co-Fe-P/NF catalysts through the chemical deposition and desalination process, where the P atoms exposed can function as electron donors for HER. Adding polymetallic elements gives the catalyst a low overpotential and increases the durability of the catalyst. Throughout the measurements, the overpotentials of Ni-Co-Fe-P/NF-3-75 were 104 and 57 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline and neutral medium, respectively [ 122 ]. Melt-spun amorphous alloys are treated with high-pressure torsion (HPT) to induce the crystallization of the amorphous matrix and increase the pores/micro-cracks/shear bands of the material to enhance the performance of the amorphous material. Chu et al. [ 123 ] synthesized amorphous Fe73.5Si13.5B9Cu1Nb3 alloy using the HPT method. HPT is a structural alteration technique in which the material is subjected to concurrent compressive and torsional forces, thereby generating plenty of defects in materials. The amorphous HPT-treated sample for 5 turns has the lowest overpotential of 174 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline electrolyte (1 mol L−1 KOH). Impressively, the overpotential decreases from 174 to 102 mV after 1000 CV cycles owing to the generation of a surface hydroxide layer beneficial for the HER process. Therefore, the strong cycling capability and durability make the amorphous Fe73.5Si13.5B9Cu1Nb3 alloy promising for applications [ 123 ]. Oxygen atoms introduced into the material lattice can change the surface electronic structure and free energy of hydrogen adsorption. Huang et al. [ 124 ] synthesized Fe-O-P nanorods (NRs) with hybridized structures by partial phosphorylation (Fig. 11(a) ). The amorphous Fe oxide (FeO x ) contained in Fe-O-P NRs accelerates the supply of hydrogen atoms in the Volmer-Herovsky reaction. On the other hand, the construction of Fe-O-P in FeO x /FeP reduces the adsorption energy of FeP for water from –0.49 to –1.07 eV (Figs. 11(b) and 11(d)), and the ΔG H* values decrease significantly for FeP(011)/FeO and FeP(111)/FeO from 0.15 to 0.12 eV and 0.33 to 0.3 eV, respectively (Fig. 11(c)), endowing the catalyst with a low overpotential of 96 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 47 mV dec−1 [ 124 ]. Melt-spun amorphous ribbons have excellent ductility and self-supporting properties, offering advantages over powdered catalysts for industrial applications. Shao et al. [ 65 ] synthesized amorphous FeMoPC HER catalysts with a unique intercalation structure employing a two-step CV-activated dechlorination approach. The sandwich structure nanoislands have large reaction regions and abundant active sites, resulting in effective HER through electrochemical cyclic voltammetry scan activation. After subsequent dechlorination, a compact protective phosphate/oxide layer with a high concentration of molybdenum at the surface is formed, and the catalyst's durability is increased. The catalyst demonstrated a low overpotential of 96 mV at 10 mA cm−2, a Tafel slope of 51 mV dec−1, and excellent stability for more than 16 h in a 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 solution for the HER. Though amorphous Fe shows better HER catalytic performance than crystalline ones, it still cannot meet the demand for highly active and stable HER catalysts. In many reports on bimetallic or trimetallic catalysts, it has been found that the doping of other elements (e.g., Ru, Ni, Co, and B) in iron-based catalysts can tune the electronic structure of the catalyst. The change in electronic structure leads to a gradual enrichment of oxygen vacancies with higher intrinsic activity or promotes the conversion of Fe to active sites with higher HER kinetics. Crystalline-amorphous interfaces, oxygen defects, and heterostructure generation can change the electron distribution around Fe, significantly enhancing the HER performance and corrosion resistance of the electrode. 5.1.2.2 Amorphous cobalt based electrocatalysts The potential HER catalytic activity and good stability of Co have promising potential for further development. However, the performance of HER in alkaline electrolytes tends to be no match for that of Pt-based catalysts at present. Therefore, developing Co-based HER electrocatalysts with excellent catalytic activity and stability in alkaline electrolytes is important. Through electron transfer, B protects the Co site from oxidation and deactivation, thus providing high stability under extreme conditions. Gupta et al. [ 69 ] synthesized amorphous Co-Ni-B nanocatalysts with superior HER performance in a wide pH range by continuously adjusting the molar ratio of Co-Ni-B. The presence of nickel increases the electron density at the Co-active sites of the catalyst, resulting in a faster HER rate. The amorphous Co-30Ni-B (Ni/(Ni+Co) = 30%) possesses the most excellent HER catalytic activity, which can reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 170 and 133 mV in pH = 7 and 14, respectively. Besides, Co-30Ni-B retains its catalytic activity satisfactorily over a thousand cycles and a running time of about 40 h, making it an excellent low-cost electrocatalyst candidate [ 69 ]. Li et al. [ 70 ] prepared structured electrodes consisting of amorphous layered nanosheets (Co-Mo-S HNSs) and amorphous thin nanosheets (Co-Mo-S TNSs) using low-temperature sulfide treatment and hydrothermal synthesis methods. The combination of Co-Mo-S nanosheets and nanoparticles gives the catalyst a porous layered structure, and the low viscosity and self-supporting structure of the electrode itself give the catalyst good activity and stability, low starting potential (90 mV) and Tafel slope (53 mV dec−1) [ 70 ]. In previous studies, Co-based oxides of crystalline/amorphous non-precious metal materials have poor HER performance under alkaline conditions. The electrons at the interface of metal phosphides can interact with each other and promote electron transfer. The HER performance of electrocatalysts can be enhanced by integrating crystalline metal phosphides with non-crystalline metal phosphides. Chen et al. [ 71 ] provided a simple, low-cost electrodeposition method and prepared crystalline/amorphous Co2P/CoMoP x nanostructures. The crystalline Co2P and amorphous CoMoP x have a large number of active interfaces between them, and these efficient active sites provide a pathway for electron transfer and thus enhance the HER catalytic performance. The catalyst shows an overpotential of 121 mV at a current density of 100 mA cm−2 and impressive electrochemical stability over 50 h [ 71 ]. The combination of amorphous structure and heterojunctions enhances the electrocatalytic performance of transition metal compounds. Shen et al. [ 125 ] synthesized crystalline-amorphous CoSe2/CoP heterojunction by phosphorylation treatment (Figs. 12(a)–(d)). Theoretical calculations showed that the formation of heterojunction weakened the H adsorption, and the introduction of amorphous structure led to a downward shift of the d-band center (Fig. 12(h) ), further weakening the H adsorption (Figs. 12(e)–(g)). The catalyst performance of HER was significantly improved with a low overpotential of 65 mV at 10 mA cm−2. When amorphous cobalt is combined with other elements, strong electron interactions are produced between the amorphous and crystalline counterparts, resulting in optimized adsorption energy for water molecules and hydrogen species. Amorphous cobalt phosphide has been shown to be a promising non-precious metal HER catalyst because of the increased number of active sites and the improved electron transfer after P doping. In addition, Co has a good affinity for oxygen, enabling amorphous Co-based alloy catalysts to produce strong oxidation resistance and protect the active sites from destruction. Unfortunately, the Co usually covers the active site and reduces the electrochemical activity. 5.1.2.3 Amorphous nickel-based electrocatalysts As a transition metal, nickel is usually used as doping to synthesize various HER catalysts. Commonly, Ni selenides, tellurides, and sulfides have good catalytic activity. The adjustment of catalyst structure is also beneficial to enhance the performance of catalysts, and nickel-based nanoparticles, nanowires, nanorods, Ni foams, etc., are developing rapidly at this stage. Considering that Ni sulfides have good HER catalytic performance under neutral and acidic conditions, with a low Tafel slope and overpotential but poor long-term stability, there is still much room for further optimization. This potential has attracted the attention of several researchers [ 126,127 ]. Lu et al. [ 128 ] prepared nickel foam (NF)-supported amorphous CoNiS x nanostructures by sulfiding the precursor CoNiCHH at room temperature. The electrodes sulfated at 25 and 120 °C were noted as CoNiS x /NF-25 and CoNiS x /NF-120, respectively, and the HER catalytic activity of CoNiS x /NF-25 was higher after comparison. The catalyst reached the current densities of 10, 20, and 100 mA cm−2 under low overpotentials of 123, 147, and 213 mV in 1 mol L−1 KOH, respectively. Besides the above-mentioned Ni foam as 3D substrates for electrocatalysis, there is great potential for using biodegradable substrates to load electrocatalysts, considering the low corrosion resistance of common metal foams. Hui et al. [ 74 ] designed an amorphous NiP alloy anchored in a natural wood framework considering the porous channel structure of wood. The wood and amorphous NiP alloy can form a stable interface, and the microchannels arranged in the wood promote electrolyte penetration and hydrogen release, thus accelerating the HER kinetic of the catalyst in alkaline solutions. By comparing different natural woods, the amorphous alloy with poplar as the framework has the highest catalytic activity and lowest Tafel slope. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 83 mV, and the catalyst showed a low Tafel slope of 73.2 mV dec−1 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Amorphous Ni-based materials are widely developed for HER electrocatalysts because of their good stability in strong alkaline solutions. Ni is generally more stable than other transition elements such as Co and Fe. However, Ni is less active and less acid resistant when used alone, which is expected to be solved by the rational construction of metal or metal oxide alloys. Amorphous binary or ternary NiMo materials are widely studied because of their good corrosion resistance, low potential in HER processes, and long-term stability, even over 100 h in pH = 0–14 by elemental doping. 5.1.2.4 Amorphous molybdenum-based electrocatalysts Molybdenum sulfide has been in demand as a catalyst for HER in recent years because of its high catalytic activity in the HER process and good stability in acidic media. The HER catalytic activity of molybdenum sulfide is mainly derived from its edge sites. Besides, sulfur content and the addition of dopants such as Co and Ni, etc., also influence the HER performance largely. At this stage, the main studies are focused on crystalline molybdenum disulfide, amorphous MoS x , and MoS x nanostructures of molecular cluster materials. Examples include mesoporous double-helical molybdenum disulfide, defect-rich molybdenum disulfide nanosheets, and molybdenum disulfide quantum dots. For crystalline molybdenum disulfide, however, active edges, conductivity, and surface area limitations continue to be issues preventing mass hydrogen production. In contrast, amorphous molybdenum sulfide (MoS x ) is inherently rich in defect sites. It is easier for application in catalytic reactions [ 129–132 ]. Compared to its crystalline counterpart, amorphous MoS2 has a higher content of unsaturated sulfur atoms on the surface, which form active sites for the HER reaction. However, it is less stable during the reaction. Compared to crystalline MoS x , amorphous MoS x has an abundance of S active sites and a lower preparation temperature, making it a very promising HER catalyst. Zheng et al. [ 133 ] used coordination polymers composed of [Mo3S13]2– clusters to synthesize amorphous nanoscale MoS x (a-MoS x ) decorated with Ni3S2 nanocrystals. By constructing the atomic structure models of [Mo3S13]2–, [Mo6S24]2– clusters and [Mo3S13]/Ni3S2 composites (Fig. 13(a) ), the shared-S in [Mo6S24]2– cluster and bridging-S in [Mo3S13]/Ni3S2 both have ΔG H* values (–0.02 and –0.05 eV) closer to zero than [Mo3S13] and 2H-MoS2 (Figs. 13(b) and 13(c)), explaining the origin of excellent activity for [Mo3S13]/Ni3S2 composites (Figs. 13(d)–(f)). Markovic et al. [ 134 ] synthesized highly active and stable CoMoS x , which is demonstrated as a pH-universal and cost-effective catalyst for the HER, and established an intimate functional link between the reactivity and stability of crystalline (CoS2 and MoS2) and amorphous (CoS x and MoS x ) hydrogen evolution catalysts. Due to the presence of in-situ electrochemical conversion/activation in electrochemical reactions, it is controversial whether the pristine amorphous state is the active species or not. Compared to the crystalline state, the amorphous MoS x can extend the HER active sites to the whole electrocatalyst surface. However, the poor electronic conductivity limits its further enhancement of catalytic performance. Gao et al. [ 135 ] used PbTe quantum dots (QDs) as a mediator of electron transfer through a novel ternary amorphous composite electrode composed of PbTe QDs, a-MoS x , and TiO2 nanotube arrays (TNAs). By studying the effect of microstructure on HER performance, it was concluded that PbTe quantum dots could significantly reduce the electrode impedance, increase the activation surface area, and enhance the energy band curvature. The electrode has good cycling stability and electrocatalytic activity. The catalyst reached the current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 under low overpotentials of 1.17 and 1.58 V. Pham et al. [ 136 ] deposited amorphous MoS x on graphene-carbon nanotube hybrids (GCNT) using electrochemical deposition at room temperature. Compared to simple, porous carbon paper or flat graphite paper, the GCNT electrode can support the deposition of MoS x at higher loads. Using the electrochemical deposition method ensures the electron transport of the deposited MoS x . With a low Tafel slope close to 40 mV dec−1, this experiment demonstrates that the deposition of MoS x on a high specific surface area electrode effectively increases the active load. Combining molybdenum sulfide with a highly conductive support can effectively enhance electron transport to the active site of the catalyst. Lee et al. [ 77 ] investigated the effect of bridging S2 2– on the catalytic activity of HER by increasing the number of bridging S2 2– on MoS x as much as possible and verified the mechanism of S2 2– site formation. The percentage of bridging S2 2– was 67% at the highest, with low starting potential (–96 mV) and Tafel slope (46 mV dec−1) and good stability of 1000 cycles (Figs. 14(a)–(f) ). Li et al. [ 137 ] synthesized thick amorphous MoS x layers loaded in N-doped graphitic carbon-based nanotube (NCNT) forest surface by low-temperature precursor decomposition. The synergistic effect between amorphous MoS x and NCNT was utilized to construct a charge transport pathway between the catalyst and the external electrode. The catalyst exhibited excellent HER catalytic activity with a low overpotential of 110 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 (Figs. 14(g)–(i)). Lin et al. [ 78 ] synthesized the nanocomposites of MoS3 and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) by wet chemical method. During the polarization process, the amorphous MoS3 was reduced to MoS2, and the catalytic activity towards HER was enhanced because the amorphous MoS2 can expose a larger number of active sites. The optimal loading rate was derived by adjusting the loading rate on MWCNTs to 33 wt%, which has a minimum overpotential of 0.13 V in 1 mol L−1 H2SO4 and good stability during long-term operation. The high corrosion resistance and low hydrogen evolution overpotential of Mo-based catalysts have attracted much interest. Molybdenum alloys, oxides, and phosphides have been explored extensively. Mo can establish a dynamic balance between the reduction at the cathode surface and oxidation in strong alkaline solutions, increasing the exchange current density while reducing the potential during HER. Mo is also a suitable element for preparing amorphous coatings and can induce amorphous structures in alloys, but it is still difficult to determine the specific active sites (e.g., MoS x ). 5.1.2.5 Other amorphous catalysts In addition to the above HER catalysts containing several mainstream transition elements, there are still some other potential candidates. Various W-based oxides, carbides, sulfides, phosphates, and selenides have good catalytic effects in acidic environments, and W atoms have better adsorption ability for hydrogen intermediates. Therefore, the W atom can somewhat replace Pt as the absorption site of Had. Many amorphous substances containing Ta elements also have good electrochemical catalytic properties. For example, amorphous Ta2O electrodes have good stability and long service life during electrocatalysis in acid solutions. Amorphous electrodes containing Ta have been widely used in photocatalysis and capacitors and have shown good performance. Wang et al. [ 82 ] prepared TaO x /Ti electrode by thermal decomposition method and demonstrated good HER catalytic properties of TaO x /Ti electrode in electrochemical experiments. The current density reached 0.1 mA cm−2 at −0.245 V (vs. RHE) in 0.704 mol L−1 Na2SO4. The coordination number of Ta-O in the TaO x /Ti electrode was analyzed using X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD), and TaO8 was found. Based on the obtained electrochemical data, the generation of TaO8 is attributed to the doping of oxygen vacancy, further demonstrated by DFT [ 82 ]. Titanium dioxide is considered an inactive component of HER due to poor electrical conductivity and unfavorable adsorption/desorption of hydrogen intermediates (Hads). However, amorphous titanium dioxide can optimize the absorption of hydrogen binding free energy. Ren et al. [ 81 ] prepared amorphous Cu-doped TiO2 catalysts with high HER activity by tuning the structural and electronic properties of titanium dioxide according to first principles calculations. Compared to M-TiO2 (monoclinic phase TiO2) and A-TiO2 (amorphous phase TiO2), Cu-A-TiO2 (Cu-doped amorphous phase) has lower ΔG H2O, ΔG W, and ΔG H* (Fig. 15(d) ) which are favorable for Volmer step to further generate adsorbed H. The rightward shift of O to the 2p orbital center (Fig. 15(e)) and narrow band gap (Fig. 15(f)) indicate that Cu-A-TiO2 has low adsorption-free energy and high electrical conductivity. Thus, the activated TiO2 expectedly shows excellent HER performance with a low overpotential of 92 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 96 mV dec−1 in alkaline 1 mol L−1 KOH media (Figs. 15(a)–(c)), which is far superior to those of the crystalline M-TiO2 (over 400 mV and 162 mV dec−1) [ 81 ]. The amorphous structure ensures a uniform distribution of metals on the catalyst surface and accelerates the kinetic process of HER under neutral conditions by binding to the W active site. Zhang et al. [ 138 ] prepared amorphous CoW(OH) x electrocatalysts by adding W to Co(OH)2 by low-temperature electrodeposition. The prepared amorphous CoW(OH) x has high HER catalytic activity in neutral electrolytes with current densities of –10 and –20 mA cm−2 at overpotentials of –73.6 and –114.9 mV in 1 mol L−1 phosphate buffer solution (Figs. 15(g) and (h)). Co enhances the ability of the catalyst to crack water into intermediate products. At the same time, W can effectively convert water to H2 and the amorphous structure enhances the interaction between W and Co. CoW(OH) x , which was proved to have good stability with no significant degradation after 10000 cycle voltammetric tests (Fig. 15(i)) [ 138 ]. Amorphous WP nanoparticles were synthesized by McEnaney et al. [ 80 ] by heating W(CO)6 and trioctylphosphine (TOP) in squalane to 320 °C for 2 h. The overpotentials were equally low at –120 and –140 mV for –10 and –20 mA cm−2, respectively. These values are more excellent than previously reported values of extremely dynamic nanostructured tungsten-based HER electrocatalysts. Subsequently, we have summarized the development of the HER electrocatalysts (Fig. 16 ). S/P atoms with high electronegativity on the surface of metal sulfides/metal phosphides serve as sites for the adsorption and desorption of H atoms. The high electronegativity leads to high bonding strength between S/P and hydrogen atoms, so the HER performance of single-crystal metal sulfide/phosphide is poor. However, exposed S/P sites or vacancies in the amorphous structure can significantly enhance the HER activity of catalysts. S atoms can also form hydrated ions with transition metal cations to enhance the HER performance of catalysts. The semi-empty d orbitals of rare earth metals can promote H adsorption, so catalysts containing rare earth elements also have good activity and stability in HER and may be able to become a hot spot for the next stage of research. 5.2 Oxygen evolution reaction 5.2.1 Precious metal-based amorphous catalysts The noble metals Ir/Ru are used as benchmark catalysts in electrolytic water separation technology. However, the high voltage required for OER and the slow kinetics hinders new catalyst development [ 139–142 ]. The unique structure and various anisotropies of amorphous materials provide new directions in the search for stable and efficient catalysts [ 143–146 ]. For example, both amorphous Ir and its oxides have the potential for catalysis, energy storage, and conversion applications. However, the scarcity and expensive nature of precious metals limit their large-scale applications, and the performances of catalysts in different environments have been enhanced by tuning the amorphous precious metal element composition, particle size, and shape [ 147–149 ]. Amorphous electrodes differ from crystalline electrodes due to the local structural properties of the surface, yet the difference between their reactivity has rarely been studied. Tsuji et al. [ 150 ] compared the electrocatalytic performance of amorphous and crystalline RuO2 films for oxygen evolution in aqueous solution. Compared to crystalline RuO2, the amorphous RuO2 surface may have structural flexibility, resulting in a negative shift of the OER onset potential by 0.03–0.06 V, and the Tafel slope is 30 mV dec−1. The results indicate that the electrocatalytic activity of amorphous RuO2 for OER is higher than that of rutile crystalline RuO2. DFT calculations show that a high amorphization degree can induce distortion-strain effects (DS), which leads the system to become meta-stable, effectively eliminating the crystal-field-splitting effect of Ru to enhance intra- and inter-orbitals electron transfer. Wang et al. [ 151 ] successfully synthesized amorphous RuTe2 porous nanorods (PNRs) as a robust OER electrocatalyst. The catalyst was subjected to a cell voltage of only 1.52 V to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in a 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 environment. Based on the obtained electrochemical data, the excellent performance of amorphous RuTe2 PNRs was attributed to the high density of defects bonded to oxygen atoms, thus forming RuO x H y species (Fig. 17(a) ). By constructing a local structure model (Fig. 17(b)) and combining the reaction mechanism of OER (Fig. 17(c)) under different pH conditions, it is demonstrated that Ru-Te can form OOH* at a lower energy barrier (1.45 eV) under acidic conditions (Figs. 17(d) and 17(f)). In alkaline conditions, the favorable bonding of both OH and O facilitates OOH formation with a lower barrier of 1.52 eV (Figs. 17(e) and 17(f)). This study provides a feasible strategy for the design and study of next-generation amorphous catalyst development [ 151 ]. Ru and Ir oxides have the highest activity among the noble metal electrocatalysts. Compared with Ru oxide, Ir oxide is more stable at high anodic potential and less corrosion-prone. Irshad et al. [ 152 ] synthesized the amorphous iridium-phosphate (Ir-Pi) OER catalyst by anodic polarization in a neutral phosphate buffer solution containing IrCl3. The large amount of phosphate and Ir centers contained in the Ir-Pi films enhanced the OER activity and possessed a lower overpotential than the Co-Pi catalyst. In the OER reaction, Ir-Pi only requires an overpotential of 220 mV in phosphate buffer (pH = 7.0). In recent years, in addition to the anodic polarization method, homogeneous solutions of Ir complexes have been used to prepare amorphous IrO x nanoparticle films. Chandra et al. [ 153 ] synthesized amorphous IrO x catalyst films from Ir precursor solutions containing Pluronic P123, Brij58, or Pluronic F127 as surfactant structure directing agents (SDA). The nanostructural morphology (nanoparticles and mesopores) of the amorphous IrO x films was adjusted by using different SDAs. The addition of SDA increased the number of Ir-sites and a higher intrinsic catalytic activity. By comparing the cyclic voltammetry data, the addition of SDA increased the catalytic current of IrO x thin films for water oxidation by 1.3–1.8 times the original [ 153 ]. At this stage, noble metal catalysts (e.g., Ir or Ru oxides) exhibit the most excellent catalytic performance in OER. The OER activity of catalysts can be further enhanced by combining supported electrocatalysts and noble metal clusters. However, the reaction mechanism is still unclear. Wang et al. [ 154 ] synthesized iridium clusters stabilized surface reconstructed oxyhydroxides on amorphous metal borides array (Ir/CoNiB). Combined with the 18O isotope-labeling experiment and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry detection, it was found that the signal peak of 16O18O was significantly enhanced, while the signal peak of 18O2 was basically unchanged, proving that the electrocatalytic OER mechanism of Ir/CoNiB was attributed to the LOM pathway. Ir/CoNiB exhibits excellent OER performance, corresponding to an overpotential of only 178 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Table 4 ). Ir/Ru-based electrocatalysts are used as benchmark OER electrocatalysts with high OER activity. Currently, amorphous noble metal oxides and phosphates have been reported extensively in OER electrocatalysts, and it has been demonstrated that amorphous materials are superior to crystalline materials. However, the problem of high cost still needs to be solved. In the current situation, exploring high-performance and inexpensive metal-based electrocatalysts is the research focus. Several transition metal hydroxides, sulfides, phosphides, etc., have been studied; however, relatively few OER electrocatalysts are available under acidic conditions, and only a few of them can maintain high activity and stability, except IrO2 and RuO2. 5.2.2 Non-precious metal-based amorphous catalysts 5.2.2.1 Amorphous iron-based electrocatalysts Researchers have found that single-metal Fe-based catalysts easily encounter severe agglomeration, corrosion of the active metal components, and leaching of anions during synthesis or electrocatalysis, thus affecting the catalytic efficiency. This problem can be solved to some extent by elemental doping, and it is widely believed that bimetallic centers lower the thermodynamic potential barrier and promote the formation of O–O bonds. Among the transition metal-based OER catalysts, Fe-based oxides, hydroxides, hydroxyl oxides, and sulfides have been studied extensively [ 172–176 ] because of their high electrocatalytic activity and low preparation cost [ 177,178 ]. It is shown that the electrons in the mixed Ni-Fe center may be induced to transfer to Ni by Fe, which enhances the charge carrier density and conductivity of the catalyst by improving the charge transfer mechanism. Tian et al. [ 179 ] used copper oxide nanotubes as a template to synthesize amorphous Ni0.75Fe0.25(OH) x hollow nanotubes rich in oxygen vacancies as electrocatalytic water oxidation catalysts. The hollow nanostructure and amorphous phase enhance the specific surface area and intrinsic activity of the catalytic site. The OER activity of the catalyst was highly dependent on the Ni-Fe ratio, with an optimum ratio of 3:1. The Ni0.75Fe0.25(OH) x catalyst has a low overpotential of 310 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Compared to Ni(OH)2, the addition of Fe resulted in a synergistic effect by partial charge transfer activation of Ni [ 179 ]. The combination of amorphous and shell structure allows the active substance and electrolyte to be fully integrated. By template-assisted method, Yue et al. [ 180 ] synthesized amorphous CoFe(OH) x catalysts with hollow and layered structures. The catalyst has a large number of hollow layered microspheres on the shell structure, which increases the number of active sites, and the addition of Fe optimizes the electronic structure and conductivity of the catalyst. CoFe(OH) x exhibits good OER catalytic performance in alkaline solution (1 mol L−1 KOH) with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 293 mV. The adsorption energy of intermediates formed at metal sites can be tuned to an optimal state by the coupling of Fe and Co compared to Fe monometallics. Zhu et al. [ 68 ] synthesized porous amorphous FeCo alloys using sodium borohydride as the reducing agent. The amorphous and porous structure resulted in the catalyst with a large number of active sites and high conductivity. When the molar ratio of Co:Fe is 2:1, and the overpotential is 290 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Amorphous catalysts possess a large number of under-coordinated metal atoms, which facilitate the rapid binding of adsorbates. Ni-Fe-based catalysts with the advantages of both amorphous and three-dimensional porous properties have rarely been synthesized and studied. Fu et al. [ 181 ] synthesized amorphous three-dimensional Ni x Fe y nanofoams (NFs) with bimetallic networks through the in-situ reduction of metal precursors. It was observed through systematic testing that the excellent performance of the catalysts may come from the variation of metal oxidation state and bonding environment (Figs. 18(a)–(c) ). In the meantime, the catalyst can still maintain high activity after 12 h stability test and possess an ultra-low overpotential of 270 mV at a current density of 100 mA cm−2. In alkaline conditions, the intrinsic activity of Co and Ni (oxy)hydroxides in OER can be enhanced approximately 100- and 500-fold, respectively. Kim et al. [ 182 ] synthesized amorphous cobalt-iron phyllosilicates (ACFPs) as highly efficient OER catalysts using a room-temperature deposition method. The Co/Fe ratio significantly influences OER performance and mechanism, among which the best-performing catalyst with 40 at% Fe delivers a low overpotential of 329 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Ma et al. [ 183 ] prepared FeNi-bimetallic infinite coordination polymers (ICPs) on nickel foam using the room-temperature solution phase method. The specific morphological structure and the synergistic effect of Fe and Ni resulted in a high catalyst activity with an overpotential of 228 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 30.3 mV dec−1. The porous channel structure and nanopores contained in the nanoreactor can change the diffusion form of reacting molecules and affect their surface ion concentrations. Li et al. [ 184 ] prepared amorphous nanoreactor (NiFe-ANR) oxides by self-catalytic reaction. The structure of the nanoreactor renders the catalyst with a local high hydroxide concentration. Under the influence of charge and mass transfer, the tip effect results in the highest OH− concentration at the top of the hemisphere, and the OH− concentration on the NiFe-ANR surface is significantly stronger (Figs. 18(d) and 18I) than NiFe-ANNR (NiFe amorphous non-nanoreactor) (Fig. 18(f)). Figs. 18(g)–(i) show that the surface current densities of NiFe-ANR and NiFe-ANNR follow the same variation guidelines with the above-mentioned OH− concentration. Thus, the synergistic effect formed by combining the amorphous structure and nanoreactor facilitates the OER process [ 184 ]. Generally, Fe has moderate or poor OER properties in alkaline environments; however, when Fe is in the amorphous state, its properties are significantly enhanced due to the increase in material ECSA. In preparing amorphous alloys, Fe doping can artificially control the amorphization rate. When the amorphous Fe-based catalyst contains Co or Ni, the higher oxidation state of Co and Ni can be maintained, allowing the catalyst to maintain high activity while improving its stability. At this stage, the research on Fe-based OER catalysts is still insufficient, and the role of Fe in the OER process still needs to be further explored. 5.2.2.2 Amorphous cobalt-based electrocatalysts Cobalt-based catalysts have been widely studied because of their abundant reserves, high stability, and low cost [ 185,186 ]. Co-based oxides are also promising OER candidates, especially spinel-type Co3O4, but the cobalt-based oxides are relatively less active for OER due to their more perfect crystal structure and poor electrical conductivity. To improve the catalytic efficiency of cobalt-based catalysts, a series of methods, such as constructing porous structures, introducing oxygen vacancies, and heteroatom doping, have been applied extensively. Recently, amorphous catalysts have attracted extensive attention due to their short-range ordered structures with significantly more unsaturated sites than crystalline electrocatalysts [ 187–191 ]. Zeng et al. [ 73 ] synthesized porous and amorphous cobalt hydroxysulfide (PA-CoS x (OH) y ) simultaneously by etching and sulfidation. The synergistic interaction of S and OH groups with oxygen vacancies in the catalyst can modulate its electronic structure, which gives it excellent OER activity and stability. The overpotential is only 320 mV when the current density is 10 mA cm−2. Loading the sample directly on nickel foam (NF) can further improve the OER performance of the sample [ 73 ]. Adding CeO x to nickel oxide and cobalt oxide adjusts the ratio of +2 valence atoms to +3 valence atoms, and the number of active sites in the corresponding oxides is adjusted. Xu et al. [ 72 ] synthesized a CoO x (Ce) catalyst by doping cerium into cobalt oxide (Figs. 19(a)–(d) ). The doping of Ce makes CoO x amorphous without changing the chemical state of Co, producing oxygen vacancies associated with Ce. The amorphous CoO x (Ce) films produced a current density of 20 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 261 mV and a current density of 100 mA cm−2 at 302 mV (Figs. 19(e)–(i)) [ 72 ]. Combining OER activity, cost-effectiveness, and natural abundance, cobalt-based catalysts, especially CoFe oxides, are considered to be promising alternatives to Ru and Ir oxides. Gong et al. [ 192 ] proposed and elucidated the working principle of the CoO x and Fe3+ catalytic system. The amorphous CoO x electrode was synthesized by electrodeposition, and Fe3+ was added directly to 1 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte. The OER activity was evaluated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and in-situ X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy. It can be concluded that the adsorption of Fe atoms with oxygen vacancies is the main reason for the high OER performance of the CoO x + Fe3+ catalyst. Electrodeposition or thermal H2 reduction is a common method for preparing amorphous materials. However, due to poor dispersion and large aggregation, amorphous CoO x prepared by electrodeposition is not conducive to electron and mass diffusion. Chen et al. [ 193 ] used air dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma to synthesize highly dispersed amorphous CoO x , which possesses the overpotential of 290 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 350 mV at 300 mA cm−2. The team found that air plasma can induce the formation of oxide species, accelerate the accumulation of oxides, and promote the gathering of amorphous clusters. It was shown that more active sites could be obtained by DBD plasma treatment, thus enhancing catalyst performance [ 193 ]. Most cobalt borate catalysts, being in powder form, need to be mixed with the binder to adhere to the electrode. The binder deteriorates gradually and has interfacial resistance during use, which is not conducive to enhancing the performance of the electrocatalyst. Xie et al. [ 194 ] provide a method for modifying cobalt-based or other metal-based three-dimensional electrode surfaces for water splitting. Core-shell catalyst (Co@Co-B/Ti) with amorphous cobalt borate nanosheets was deposited on a Ti mesh by in-situ conversion strategy, which reaches a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with only 329 mV in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The in-situ synthesis method makes the nanosheets and metal substrates more closely linked and enhances the conductivity of the material. It is suitable for preparing an efficient OER catalyst within a wide pH [ 194 ]. Oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, and borides of Co have been reported, and their amorphous materials show greater flexibility than their crystalline derivatives. The distance between adjacent atoms of Co–O, and Co–Co bonds can produce greater contraction and relaxation in amorphous Co-based materials at high current densities, leading to further valence elevation of Co (Co2+ → Co3+/Co4+), thus resulting in more oxygen vacancies and higher electronic conductivity, which provides a new idea for the preparation of amorphous materials at high current densities. The doping of high valence metal ions in amorphous Co-based catalysts can maintain the high valence state of Co while decreasing the valence state of the doped ions, resulting in higher OER activity. 5.2.2.3 Amorphous nickel-based electrocatalysts Nickel-based materials have been heavily investigated because of their high electrical conductivity, high corrosion resistance, and OER activity [ 195–198 ]. In the construction of catalysts based on Ni/Co, Ni/Fe, etc., Ni introduction can modulate the catalytic activity of the catalysts, and the synergistic effect between Ni and Co, Fe, etc. is usually shown [ 199–201 ]. Nickel-based oxides/hydroxides (such as NiO x , Ni(OH)2, and NiOOH) are considered more promising OER catalysts. However, the low conductivity and poor stability of the catalysts still need improvement. At this stage, nickel foams (NF) are also commonly used due to their high electrical conductivity, and there is also potential to enhance catalyst stability by preparing nickel-based 3D metal oxides/hydroxides and sulfides [ 202 ]. Recently, three-dimensional metal phosphides and metal-phosphorus alloys have been intensively studied for OER. Relative research work has shown that phosphorus facilitates the formation of phosphide/(hydro)-oxide core/shell structures. Xu et al. [ 203 ] synthesized an OER catalyst with NiOOH@amorphous Ni-P bilayers on ZrO2 mesh by chemical deposition and robocasting. The phosphide contributes to forming a stable oxide/hydroxide surface film at the electrode, leading to the production of a phosphide/(hydro)oxide core/shell structure, which improves the corrosion resistance and catalytic performance of the OER electrode. Among a series of control samples, the catalyst with a coating time of 2 h shows the lowest overpotential of 326 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Moreover, its OER activity will be further improved after 10 h of stability test, and only 286 mV is needed to reach 10 mA cm−2 [ 203 ]. NiFeO x H y -based catalyst is a promising OER catalyst, and introducing a third element to further enhance the electrocatalyst performance is beneficial to elucidate the OER mechanism at the active site. Lim et al. [ 204 ] synthesized Amorphous Zn-doped NiFeO x H y on the Ni foil by chemical deposition and electrochemical activation. By comparing with NiFeO x H y , the doping of Zn produced an induced effect to optimize the binding of surface intermediates (Figs. 20(a) and (b) and (d) ), thus enhancing the OER activity of the catalyst, which achieves a low overpotential of 250 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 20(c)) [ 204 ]. Prussian blue was used as an iron source and structural template, providing a new strategy for synthesizing amorphous materials rich in oxygen vacancies. Wang et al. [ 76 ] synthesized amorphous porous nickel hydroxide nanolayers on carbon paper (CP) by a two-step electrodeposition and alkaline etching process. The synergistic effect between Ni and Fe and the efficient electron and mass transfer of the carbon paper resulted in good catalyst performance. The overpotentials were 261 and 303 mV at current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively. Luo et al. [ 205 ] synthesized 3D amorphous NiFeIr x /Ni core-shell nanowire@nanosheets (NW@NSs) by immobilizing Ir on NiFe scaffolds through a one-step reduction process. By constructing a model of intermediates in the OER (Fig. 20(g)), it was found that the Gibbs free-energy values of NiFeIr x /Ni in the OER rate-determining step decreased from 1.78 to 1.62 eV compared to NiFe/Ni (Fig. 20(h)), indicating that the synergistic effect between Ir atoms and the substrates leads to the enhanced catalytic activity of NiFeIr x /NiNW@NSs. The catalyst reached the current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 under low overpotentials of 200 and 250 mV in 1 mol L−1 KOH and exhibited excellent long-term stability over 12 h at 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 20(e) and 20(f)) [ 205 ]. In non-noble metal-based catalysts, the electrocatalytic performance and corrosion resistance in an alkaline environment can be significantly improved by adding anion-intercalated hydroxides. Ma et al. [ 206 ] synthesized the core-shell NiNH@Fe(OH)3 nanostructure (amorphous Fe(OH)3 loaded in nickel nitrate hydroxide) on NF by interfacial hydrolysis method, and the catalyst had good stability due to the strong interaction between NiNH and Fe(OH)3, an overpotential of 212 mV at a current density of 100 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 49 mV dec−1 in alkaline electrolyte (1 mol L−1 KOH). Currently, most of the studied amorphous Ni-based catalysts are doped with Co or Fe elements.
