The addition of Fe can induce charge transfer between Ni and Fe centers or induce the transformation of the material into an amorphous state, and the addition of Ni can increase the adsorption of catalyst for OH- or increase the number of active sites, thus enhancing the OER performance. Meanwhile, the presence of Fe affects the redox properties of Ni, making it more difficult to oxidize while maintaining the activity and stability of Ni in the OER process. However, adding Fe and Co may cause the catalyst to adsorb the intermediates too strongly in the OER reaction and reduce the reaction rate, which is expected to be improved by constructing nanostructures and suitable doping ratios of the elements. 5.2.2.4 Amorphous molybdenum-based electrocatalysts Mo-based materials, an important component of transition metal-based materials, have been little studied due to their limited catalytic activity. Molybdenum disulfide is widely used due to its significant chemisorption effect despite its low electrical conductivity and poor durability. Amorphous catalysts can generate more active sites, so constructing molybdenum-based catalysts with amorphous structures may be more catalytically active [ 206–209 ]. Amorphous catalysts can change from the resting state to the catalytically active state, resulting in a larger number of active sites. Therefore, constructing amorphous structures is more favorable than crystalline molybdenum oxide for catalytic activity. Guo et al. [ 210 ] synthesized cobalt-doped amorphous MoO x (CoMoO x ) with core-shell structure by hydrothermal reaction. By comparing Co-MoO x with different Co/Mo ratios, amorphous MoO x without cobalt doping, and crystalline MoO2, the experimental data demonstrated that the charge transfer process and active sites of the catalysts were well optimized because of the doping and amorphous structure properties of cobalt. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 340 mV, and the catalyst showed a low Tafel slope of 49 mV dec−1 in 1 mol L−1 KOH [ 210 ]. The *OH → *O + *H reaction is accelerated by capturing protons from hydroxyl groups on the oxide surface through MoS x as a proton acceptor. Using a one-step solvothermal method, Gan et al. [ 211 ] synthesized amorphous iron-cobalt-molybdenum oxide flakes containing MoS x and sulfate (FCMOS). The hydrogen bond formed between the sulfate of *OOH and the H atom allows the energy separation of *OOH and *OH close to the thermodynamic value, thus producing excellent OER activity. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 260 mV, and a low Tafel slope of 47 mV dec−1 was acquired in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Xu et al. [ 212 ] synthesized three-dimensional nickel sulfide/amorphous molybdenum sulfide nanosheet arrays on the surface of conductive NF substrates by a solvothermal method. The synergistic effect between MoS x and Ni3S2 and the high specific surface area of the three-dimensional electrodes lead to enhanced catalytic activity. The catalyst showed an onset potential of 165 mV and a Tafel slope of 67.5 mV dec−1. The catalyst exhibited long-term stability in an alkaline electrolyte (1 mol L−1 KOH), and the LSV polarization curves did not change much after 1000 potential cycles compared to the initial result [ 212 ]. The concentration of amorphous structures and anionic defects in ultrathin nanomaterials can significantly enhance catalytic performance. Shao et al. [ 213 ] synthesized ultrathin amorphous Mo-FeS nanosheets (Mo-FeS NSs) with abundant sulfur defects by hydrothermal method. Based on the electrochemical data, the accelerated electron and mass transfer on oxygen-containing intermediates was attributed to the amorphous structure-induced remodeling and sulfur-rich defects, further demonstrated by DFT. Compared with FeS (1.99 eV) and Mo-FeS NPs (2.41 eV), the lower Gibbs free energies (1.79 eV) for the rate-determining step of Mo-FeS NSs (Figs. 21(d)–(f) ) and the Fe-d orbital generation endow the material excellent electrical conductivity (Figs. 21(g)–(i)). The overpotential of 210 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 21(a) and 21(c)) and a Tafel slope of 50 mV dec−1 (Fig. 21(b)) were observed in 1 mol L−1 KOH [ 213 ]. The thermodynamic and kinetic activity of the OER can be enhanced by properly matching the energy levels to the OER equilibrium potential and enriched active sites. Cai et al. [ 214 ] used a solvothermal method to synthesize amorphous FeCoMo/CoMo carbonate hydroxide microspheres. A mechanistic study using a rotating ring-disk electrode confirmed the superior Faraday efficiency (97.7%) of the four-electron pathway based on the obtained electrochemical data. The catalyst has a low overpotential (232 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and small Tafel slope (46 mV dec−1) in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Compared with crystalline alloys of Mo, amorphous alloys containing Mo have a stronger cation diffusion ability and are more likely to form an alloy oxide (hydroxide) layer with OER activity. The atomic structure of Mo is similar to those of Co and Ni, which is very favorable for doping reactions. The high-valence metal ions formed by Mo can modulate the electronic structure of surrounding atoms and enhance the OER performance of the catalyst. However, the inevitable phase separation between high-valence dopants and metal matrix hinders their modulation effects, and the role of amorphous Mo in the OER process remains obscure. 5.2.2.5 Other amorphous catalysts In addition to the several common types of OER catalysts discussed above, transition metal oxides such as copper oxides, chromium oxides, and manganese oxides have been extensively investigated as OER catalysts. The high abundance, low toxicity, and unique redox properties of manganese make manganese-based catalysts a promising electrode material. Most of the manganese oxides are composed of [MnO6] octahedra with different connections, which can produce a large number of manganese oxides/hydroxyl oxides with different crystal structures. Guan et al. [ 215 ] constructed single-atom manganese coordinated to nitrogen and sulfur species in two-dimensional graphene nanosheets (MnNSG) as an active and durable OER catalyst with a low overpotential of 296 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Theoretical calculations also revealed that the Mn-N3S sites in the graphene matrix are the most active sites for the OER. CuO-Cu2O redox can induce a change in the valence of nickel and form layered composites with other OER catalysts in close arrangement and strong interactions, which contribute to charge transfer and improve the conductivity of electrodes. Many elements can significantly modulate the catalytic activity of catalysts after doping. For example, Cr accelerates the pre-oxidation of Co2+ to higher valence species, which leads to a significant increase in catalytic activity [ 216,217 ]. Antoni et al. [ 218 ] deposited manganese oxide nanosheets on carbon nanotubes (MnO x /NCNT) as OER catalysts in alkaline electrolytes. Some deposited products formed bicrystalline manganese dioxide with amorphous characteristics, and the catalyst had high OER activity due to the formation of γ-MnOOH. The as-prepared catalyst has a low overpotential of 370 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 75 mV dec−1. This experiment provides a novel route for catalyst synthesis. Adding Cr to the electrocatalyst can promote the catalytic activity of Co in the OER process. Chen et al. [ 219 ] synthesized a series of amorphous ternary Co-Fe-Cr (oxy)hydroxides by a low-temperature co-deposition method with a tuned ratio of doping elements. The catalyst exhibited a low overpotential of 232 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH (Figs. 22(d) and 22(e) ) and a two orders higher turnover frequency (0.23 s−1) than monometallic Co (oxy)hydroxides (Fig. 22(f)). The formation of high-valent Co4+ is beneficial to the OER during the Co (oxy)hydroxide reaction, and DFT calculations show that the addition of Cr and Fe significantly reduces ΔG(Co2+ → Co3+) and ΔG(Co3+ → Co4+) of the catalyst (Fig. 22(a)), further promoting the formation of Co3+ and maintaining the stability of Co4+. β-CoOOH is regarded as the most thermodynamically favorable Co hydroxide surface under OER potentials, and the volcano diagram also shows that doping Fe and Cr in β-CoOOH can produce surface sites with high OER activity (Figs. 22(b) and 22(c)) [ 219 ]. The growth of active materials on an amorphous framework facilitates the generation of layered nanocomposite structures and increases the number of electron transport channels. CuO-Cu2O redox can change the valence state of nickel and promote charge transfer. The growth of NiOOH@CuO-Cu2O on an amorphous Co(OH)2 nanosheet increases the number of electron transfer channels and enhances the OER activity. The current density reached 20 mA cm−2 at 262 mV in 1 mol L−1 KOH [ 220 ]. Amorphous materials are rich in defects, but the kinetics of charge transfer are limited due to low conductivity, which facilitates the rational design of electrocatalysts by changing the ratio of crystalline to amorphous states in electrocatalysts. Kuang et al. [ 221 ] used the cation exchange method to synthesize cobalt-vanadium-iron (oxy)hydroxide (CoV-Fe0.28) nanosheets. The synergistic effect of Co, V, and Fe cations in the catalyst modulated the local coordination environment and electronic structure, and their own amorphous/crystalline heterostructure also increased the number of active sites. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 215 mV in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Subsequently, we have summarized the development of OER electrocatalysts (Fig. 23 ). In amorphous metal sulfides, the presence of sulfate ions helps to enhance the hydrophilicity of the material and enhance the contact between the electrolyte and the electrocatalyst, further enhancing the OER performance of the catalyst. Similar to metal phosphides, desulfurization, and oxidation of metal sulfides occurring during the OER process can obtain more porous metal oxides/hydroxides with higher OER activity. Increasing oxygen vacancies introducing oxygen dopants or surface oxidation enhances the number of catalytic sites effectively. Many achievements have been made in the field of OER with amorphous catalysts. However, relatively few catalysts show excellent OER performance under acidic conditions, except for IrO2 and RuO2, and only a few alloys, MnO x , etc., have high OER activity and stability. 5.3 Overall water splitting 5.3.1 Precious metal-based amorphous catalysts Hydrogen is one of the most attractive energies to replace fossil fuels, responding to the demand for clean and efficient energy sources. It is difficult to obtain high concentrations of H+ and OH- simultaneously in the same electrolyzer, and the different reaction mechanisms of OER and HER also make it inaccessible to catalyze two reactions at the same active site. Thus, developing highly active catalysts for OWS in the same electrolyte is a major challenge. Theoretically, Ru-based materials have efficient OER activity [ 222 ], and Ru–H bonding can reduce the hindrance of hydrogen atom desorption, making them excellent candidates for overall water splitting [ 223 ]. During catalyst preparation, carbon materials, metal oxides, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as OER/HER catalyst carriers, can promote nanoparticle dispersion and provide immobilization and protection, endowing a new idea for combining OWS catalysts. Li et al. [ 224 ] synthesized an Ir-based catalyst (IrO2@Ir-MOF) by ultrafine IrO2 particles uniformly distributed in amorphous Ir-based MOF, and the exposed carboxyl groups in Ir-MOF ligands enhanced the hydrophilicity and availability of OH−, thus promoting OER/HER activity. The IrO2@Ir-MOF||IrO2@Ir-MOF couple can still maintain high activity after 120 h stability test, and only 1.53 V is needed to reach 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The amorphous WO3 can induce lattice distortion, and by combining with Ir-based electrocatalysts, it can maintain electrocatalyst performance while reducing the Ir ratio. Fan et al. [ 225 ] synthesized the coral-like Ir1–x W x @NC electrode that increases the number of intrinsic active sites in IrO2 by introducing amorphous WO3 between IrO2 nanoparticles and NC, resulting in lattice distortion of crystalline IrO2. The team built a two-electrode electrolytic cell for monolithic water cleavage in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4, and the current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 1.6 V. During annealing, the metal Ir can aggregate and form an amorphous Ir oxide layer. The amorphous Ir oxide layer can prevent the electrochemical dissolution of Ir in acidic solutions and the aggregation in alkaline and neutral solutions. Luo et al. [ 226 ] synthesized amorphous iridium nanorods (Ir-NR/C) in a 300 °C annealing process. Based on the obtained electrochemical data, the OWS ability of the catalyst is attributed to the formation of the amorphous iridium oxide (IrO x ) layer on the Ir-NR/C surface and is further demonstrated by DFT. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 1.55 and 1.57 V (vs. RHE), and the catalyst showed a low Tafel slope of 81.5 and 105.4 mV dec−1 in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 and 1 mol L−1 KOH, respectively. Ru nanoparticles have superior oxygen evolution performance and can expose more hydrogen evolution sites than commercial RuO2. Yang et al. [ 227 ] embedded Ru/Cu-doped RuO2 complexes into an amorphous carbon skeleton using the MOF template method. The doping of Cu in RuO2 nanoparticles and the intrinsic OER activity of Ru nanoparticles give the catalyst excellent OWS ability, and DFT further demonstrated this. The catalyst reached the current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 under 1.47 and 1.67 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The use of ultra-thin two-dimensional (2D) layered double hydroxide nanosheets (LDHs) with a high surface area can facilitate the preparation of single-atom catalysts (SACs). Zhai et al. [ 223 ] synthesized amorphous Ru1/D-NiFe LDH on NF by electrodeposition and etching. DFT calculations showed that Ru1/D-NiFe LDH can effectively modulate the H adsorption energy and promote O-O coupling during OWS. Compared to Ru (Figs. 24(a) and 24(c) ), the Gibbs free energy of the rate-determining step is lower (Figs. 24(b) and 24(d)) when Ru-O is used as the active site (from 1.71 to 0.38 eV), indicating that Ru-O promotes O2 generation and enhances the intrinsic activity of HER and OER. Thus, the catalyst demonstrates economically beneficial low cell voltages of 1.44V at 10 mA cm−2 (Table 5 ). Pt-based and Ru/Ir-based metal oxides are the most superior electrocatalysts in HER and OER, respectively, but the high cost and material scarcity limit their large-scale applications. Meanwhile, Pt-based catalysts are more sensitive to pH changes, and the HER activity in alkaline media is 2–18 orders of magnitude lower than that in acidic environments. In recent years, the strategy of amorphous noble metal and non-precious metal alloying to form bimetallic alloy nanoparticles has been widely used, and the abundant unsaturated sites and high surface energy will greatly improve the catalytic performance of amorphous alloy catalysts compared with traditional alloy catalysts. The rational use of the conformational relationship of electrons between amorphous noble metal alloys is expected to improve the activity and stability of catalysts while reducing the noble metal content. 5.3.2 Non-precious metal-based amorphous catalysts 5.3.2.1 Amorphous iron-based electrocatalysts Fe is one of the most abundant elements in reserve on earth, and some Fe sulfides have been used as electrocatalysts for HER, but they have never been shown to have potential as OER catalysts. Among the known Fe oxides, especially amorphous oxides, are active for OER, but the catalytic activity is still low. Enhancing the OWS ability of catalysts by doping Fe with other metallic elements is more attractive. Amorphous NiFe sulfides can optimize the electronic structure, promote the kinetics of the HER process, and provide active sites for OER. Furthermore, adding Co can synergistically affect the Fe ions and promote electrical conductivity by generating Co ions in the oxidation state, providing a new impetus to study low-cost Fe-containing OWS catalysts [ 255–257 ]. Considering these advantages, the synthesis of Fe-based electrocatalytic materials has been widely explored, especially Fe-S-based catalysts. However, their catalytic activities and durability are possibly much lower than those of Pt-based and other non-precious metal transition metal-based electrocatalysts. Zou et al. [ 257 ] synthesized mackinawite FeS nanosheets on iron foam (FeS/IF) for generating highly active electrocatalysts for both HER and OER (Fig. 25(a) ). During the OER process, the ferrous sulfide nanosheets are completely transformed into porous amorphous FeO x films, thus improving the efficiency of OER. During the HER process, core-shell Fe@FeO x S y was in-situ generated on FeS nanosheets (Fe-H2cat) to facilitate the reaction. The underwater superaerophobic surface gives excellent mass transport properties of Fe-H2, promoting the desorption of H2 gas (Figs. 25(b)–(d)). Compared to O-covered Fe (111), the ΔG H* of the active site in O/S-covered Fe (111) is closer to zero, indicating that the presence of S atoms promotes the HER activity of the catalyst (Figs. 25(e) –(g)). The team constructed an alkaline electrolyzer (1 mol L−1 KOH) with the above two Fe-based derivatives as cathode and anode catalysts, respectively. The catalyst can still maintain high activity after 30 h stability test and possess an ultra-low potential of 1.65 and 1.80 V at 10 and 100 mA cm−2 [ 257 ]. NiFe alloy is considered a promising bifunctional electrocatalyst due to its low price and good electrical conductivity. Lian et al. [ 258 ] synthesized amorphous Ni-Fe-P alloys by the one-step direct-current electrodeposition method. In alkaline media, the good electrical conductivity and the “ensemble effect” of metal phosphides have great potential in OWS. The preparation of OWS catalysts and the doping of P-atoms avoids the slow H2 kinetics caused by using pure metals. The catalyst can still maintain high activity after 12 h stability test and possess an ultra-low potential of 1.62 V at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 30 wt% KOH solution. The mechanism of metal and non-metal doping in amorphous catalysts has been extensively studied. However, the synergistic effect of metal and metal-like doping still needs to be investigated in many aspects. Tang et al. [ 59 ] synthesized the amorphous nanocompound Ni-Fe-P-B by the co-reduction method. The combination of metal and metalloid and the unique amorphous structure make Ni-Fe-P-B an excellent catalyst for overall water splitting. When the catalyst is loaded on carbon paper, the catalyst possesses an ultra-low potential of 1.58 V at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH and can still maintain high activity after 60 h stability test. The adsorption energy of CoWO4 was optimized by adding Fe, Ni, Mn, and Co ions to enhance the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalyst. Wu et al. [ 259 ] prepared an amorphous Fe-doped CoWO4 bifunctional catalyst using the co-precipitation method. The abundant disordered defects provided by the amorphous structure of the catalyst effectively bind to OH and increase the concentration of the edge sites, while the synergistic effect with iron ions promotes electrical conductivity. The as-prepared catalyst has a low potential of 1.55 V at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Recently, metal phosphides have shown promise as electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. Amorphous phosphides are able to further enhance the P content compared to crystalline structures. Xu et al. [ 260 ] synthesized Amorphous np-(Ni x Fe1–x )4P5 by electrochemical dealloying method. The negatively charged P can capture the proton generated during HER, so the phosphate can provide abundant edge sites during OER. The electron-donating reaction caused by the substitution of nickel for iron enhances the catalytic efficiency. The catalyst can still maintain high activity after 20 h stability test and possess an ultra-low potential of 1.62 V at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Compared to hematite catalysts, amorphous iron oxides have more bridging or terminal water/hydroxyl ligands, favoring the OER/HER process. At this stage, amorphous FeNi alloys are considered ideal catalysts for water splitting due to their ability to influence orbital hybridization and cause changes in the binding energy for hydrogen and oxygen adsorption, which improves the stability of HER and OER. Amorphous Ni-Fe oxides with disordered structures can reduce the activation energy barrier for intermediat OOH- formation, which may be the source of OER activity. The introduction of B in amorphous Fe-based catalysts is also a means to modulate the d-band center of Fe site and optimize the adsorption of OER/HER intermediates. 5.3.2.2 Amorphous cobalt-based electrocatalysts Co-based materials are also attractive catalysts for OWS because of their low energy barriers. A large number of teams have studied Co sulfides, nitrides, phosphides, etc. Cobalt-based nitrides have excellent catalytic ability for OWS due to the special electronic structure of the N-coordination metal sites and the high activity of individual catalytic sites. In the Co-based phosphides, P atoms can reach negative charge density from the transfer of Co and act as the active center. However, the catalytic activity of the Co-based catalysts is still far below expectations, and improvements in the material structure are needed. Among the available candidate electrocatalysts, transition metal nitrides (TMNs) have a wide range of material types and tunable surface properties that facilitate the development of efficient catalysts. Zou et al. [ 261 ] prepared a new type of efficient OWS electrocatalyst by in-situ coupling amorphous cobalt nitride (CoN x ) nanoparticles within three-dimensional nitrogen-doped graphene aerogel (NGA). NGA provides the channel for electron transfer, and the amorphous structure of CoN x particles and N-doped graphene frameworks provide fully exposed edge sites. The as-prepared catalyst has a low potential of 1.71 V at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH (Fig. 26 ). By studying different forms of pure cobalt sulfide electrocatalysts, it was found that their catalytic activity in OWS was still unsatisfactory. Souleymen et al. [ 262 ] synthesized amorphous CoS x non-layered and freestanding nanosheets via microwave-assisted liquid-phase growth of a Co(OH)2 precursor post-sulfurized at room temperature. The mesoporous feature offered more active sites from the edge localized atoms with a lower coordination number. The large surface area and two-dimensional conductive catalyst channels accelerate the transfer of charge and mass. The catalyst reached the current density of 20 mA cm−2 under a low potential of 1.55 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The cobalt selenide has been used as an OER catalyst in alkaline media and HER catalyst in acidic media; however, it still needs to be explored as an OWS catalyst. Liu et al. [ 263 ] grew amorphous CoSe films on Ti mesh (a-CoSe/Ti) using the electrodeposition method. Ti mesh as an electrocatalyst substrate has the characteristics of low cost, good conductivity, and large pores compared with conventional carriers, which can promote effective diffusion of electrolyte and generated gas. The catalyst reached the current density of 10 mA cm−2 under a low potential of 1.65 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Adding Co0 atoms and Sn to the electrocatalyst makes it possible to improve the conductivity of the catalyst while providing HER active sites. Menezes et al. [ 264 ] synthesized amorphous cobalt stannide (CoSn2) nanocrystals by the solution chemistry technique. Under a strong alkaline electrolyte, the loss of tin in the lattice and oxidation of Co produce amorphous active CoO x (H), forming a catalytically active structure of OER. The team prepared OWS devices by loading CoSn2 on NF, which reaches a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with only 1.55 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Co-based electrocatalysts are readily oxidized to metal oxy-hydroxides, which can significantly enhance the OER activity of the catalysts. Wang et al. [ 265 ] synthesized OWS catalysts by electrodeposition of amorphous Co-Mo-P-O on NF. Mo and P interact structurally with Co to form an amorphous state of the catalyst, which increases the number of active sites and promotes charge transfer. The catalyst reached the current density of 10 mA cm−2 under low potential of 1.57 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The introduction of additional elements in amorphous Co has been shown to accelerate the reaction kinetics, and the increase in electrical conductivity and localized electric dipole can promote the production of layered and multilayered amorphous morphology of the catalyst. Adding Ni and Fe can modulate the d-band center of Co and enhance the ECSA and the chemical reaction rate at the surface of the catalyst. Compared with the crystalline Co, the amorphous Co-P has a higher surface defect density and a flexible structure with a large number of unsaturated adsorption sites, and the ECSA is about 2.5 times higher than that of its crystalline counterpart. Adding P can reduce the H+ adsorption energy of the amorphous cobalt-based catalysts in HER while promoting the generation of more Co surface active sites in the OER process. The synergistic effect of multi-metal catalysts is further utilized to make the amorphous Co-based catalysts with more excellent HER/OER activity, thus promoting their application in alkaline electrolyzers. 5.3.2.3 Amorphous nickel-based electrocatalysts Among the catalysts containing Ni elements, NiSe2, NiFe-based, and NiCo-based (oxides) hydroxides are considered as several attractive OER and HER electrocatalysts. However, the high overpotential and energy barriers largely affect the application of Ni-based catalysts, and the development of Ni-based catalysts with unique structures is of importance. In the OWS study, the active edge sites were optimized for a large number of sulfur compounds, especially MS x . Li et al. [ 266 ] synthesized the interwoven NiS/NiS2 structure with an amorphous interface by one-step low-temperature thermal sulfidation. In the overall water splitting, the partial phase transition from NiS2 to NiS induced the formation of an amorphous NiS/NiS2 interface, and the separation of H* and H intermediates to different interfacial sites, which reduced the interfacial energy and charge transfer resistance. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 1.62 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Amorphous MOFs are highly disordered framework structures that provide a pathway for preparing OWS catalysts under alkaline conditions by combining with Ni elements. Qiao et al. [ 267 ] synthesized amorphous FeNi bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (Ni1–x Fe x -HP) by the facile solvothermal method. Ni1–x Fe x -HP is a hollow polyhedron with mesoporous walls, and the unique structure enhances the synergistic effect of Ni, nickel monoxide, and N-graphene on HER, thus accelerating the charge and mass transport. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 1.57 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. During overall water splitting, NiSe2 gradually transforms into amorphous Ni(OH)2/NiOOH heterojunctions, which can generate a self-reconstruction mechanism through oxidation induction. Zhai et al. [ 268 ] prepared OWS amorphous NiSe2 nanoparticles/carbon fiber paper (NSN/CFP) electrodes by homogeneously anchoring metallic NiSe2 nanoparticles on conductive cylindrical carbon fibers. The NiSe2 nanoparticles were prepared via a selenization process using nickel monoxide. The structure can effectively reduce the aggregation of nanoparticles and form a homogeneous interface, which helps to promote the catalytic rate through the effective charge exchange. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 1.66 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. NiCo-based (oxy)hydroxides are a promising catalyst for overall water splitting; however, they have semiconductor properties that require additional overpotentials to overcome. Li et al. [ 269 ] used the core-shell nanowire array on Ni foam (NiCo2O4@Ni x Co y LDH/NF) as a catalyst for overall water splitting. The vertically aligned porous NiCo2O4 nanowires can provide a large active surface area but poor catalytic activity. The amorphous structure of Ni0.796Co LDH facilitates the adsorption of intermediates on the surface, which may reduce the binding energy of reaction intermediates (HO*, O*, HOO*) to the catalyst surface, but the poor electrical conductivity makes it difficult to obtain a large specific surface area. The advantages of the catalyst were fully exploited by hybridizing NiCo2O4 and Ni x Co y LDH, which reaches a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with only 1.6 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Studies have shown that amorphous nanomaterials can improve the OWS ability of electrocatalysts while maintaining good durability. Xu et al. [ 270 ] synthesized amorphous NiFe nanotube arrays on nickel foam (NiFe NTAs-NF) using the electrodeposition method. The synergistic effect between Ni and Fe produced more active sites and enhanced mass and charge transport capabilities. The nanotube array structure of the catalyst provides a larger specific surface area and fully exposed edge sites. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 1.62 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The adsorption energies and activation energy barriers of intermediates in the HER/OER catalytic process are reflected by the d-band (ɛ d) and p-band centers (ɛ p) to the Fermi level. Liu et al. [ 271 ] constructed an amorphous-crystalline heterostructure by growing amorphous CoBO x on 3D NiSe (CoBO x /NiSe) (Fig. 27(b) ). The charge redistribution at the CoBO x /NiSe interface can effectively modulate the surface electronic structure of the system due to the incorporation of d-p orbitals at the amorphous-crystalline interface (Fig. 27(a)). The performance of the catalyst is enhanced by the enhanced d-p band center proximity (shortened Δɛd-p ), enabling the optimization of the adsorption/desorption equilibrium of intermediates (e.g., H*, OOH*) (Figs. 27(c)–(g)). The excellent stability of amorphous Ni-based catalysts makes them strong candidates for industrial water electrolysis, but the HER/OER performance and stability of most catalysts at high current densities are still unsatisfactory. Future studies should be compared with the standards of actual electrolytic water in the industry to improve the versatility of amorphous Ni-based materials and ensure the application in a wide pH range, especially in alkaline conditions. 5.3.2.4 Amorphous molybdenum-based electrocatalysts Layered molybdenum disulfide is a typical HER electrocatalyst with poor OER activity. The addition of transition metals (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni) can further promote the performance of molybdenum disulfide in the HER process by changing the electronic structure around the molybdenum disulfide and accelerating the slow kinetics. Metal sulfides and metal phosphides (e.g., cobalt sulfide, nickel sulfide, cobalt phosphide, and nickel phosphide) are considered to be effective catalysts for OER in alkaline solutions, and the combination of molybdenum disulfide and cobalt phosphide/sulfide has promising applications as a bifunctional HER/OER catalyst in overall water splitting. Amorphous molybdenum disulfide materials have more exposed edge sites and defects than crystalline molybdenum disulfide and, therefore, have higher HER activity. Thus, preparing amorphous molybdenum sulfide materials could be of interest as a low-cost electrocatalyst candidate. Metal sulfides with nanostructures, especially Co-based compounds, can effectively promote OER, and the catalysts can possess both OER and HER activities by combining with amorphous Mo/S. Shan et al. [ 272 ] synthesized the hierarchical amorphous CoMoS x chalcogen on NF by in-situ metathesis reaction (Fig. 28(f) ). The existence of S vacancies (Table 6 ) makes the Co-S coordination number in the CoMoS x much lower than that in the theoretical Co-S6 structure (Figs. 28(a)–(e)). It is also pointed out that the superhydrophilic and supergasophobic properties of CoMoS x /NF promote mass transfer by facilitating the entry of electrolytes and ensuring the rapid release of bubbles. Thus, excellent HER performance has been obtained, and the catalyst CoMoS x can still maintain high activity after 100 h stability test and possess an ultra-low potential of 1.89 V at the current density of 500 mA cm−2. Synthesizing amorphous carbon layers wrapped with Co on molybdenum disulfide by annealing can effectively prevent electrocatalyst corrosion and maintain long-term OWS activity. Lin et al. [ 273 ] synthesized amorphous Co/Co9S8-MoS2 as the OWS catalyst by preparing amorphous carbon-coated Co/Co9S8 nanoparticles on MoS2. Excessive H2S generated in the decomposition process of ammonium thiomolybdate can partially sulfurize carbon-coated Co nanoparticles, and Co/Co9S8 mixed phases will be formed on the MoS2. The strong chemical coupling of Co/CoS x to molybdenum disulfide nanohybrids and the protection of amorphous carbon shells result in excellent stability of Co/CoS x -MoS2. The current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 325 mV in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Hybridization of OER and HER materials is a strategy that has been successfully developed for synthesizing OWS catalysts. Yoon et al. [ 274 ] synthesized amorphous CoS-Co(OH)2@aMoS2+x hybrid catalyst by binder-free CoS-doped β-Co(OH)2@amorphous MoS2+x on NF. The unsaturated sulfur sites of amorphous MoS2+x and the doping of CoS in β-Co(OH)2 enhance the HER and OER activities of the catalysts. β-Co(OH)2 and aMoS2+x are tightly bound to each other due to the bridging of CoS x . The catalyst can still maintain high activity after 100000 s stability test and possess an ultra-low potential of 1.58 V at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. In overall water splitting, amorphous Mo-based materials mostly appear as amorphous alloys. The addition of Mo can induce the catalyst to produce an amorphous structure, resulting in a high density of active sites and larger ECSA. Amorphous Mo can significantly enhance the adsorption capacity of Ni active sites to HER active intermediates and produce more target intermediates for OER. The dissolution of Mo during the reaction process can also provide space for the adsorption of hydroxyl groups. At this stage, there are fewer studies on amorphous Mo-based catalysts in overall water splitting, which is still not explored. 5.3.2.5 Other amorphous catalysts In addition to the elements described above, W-based, Cr-based, and Cu-based compounds are also of great interest in the study of OWS catalysts. Cr3+ has a special electronic configuration that facilitates electron capture and charge transfer. For example, doping Cr3+ in Co oxides increases their electrical conductivity. DFT shows that doping Cu in ruthenium oxides can effectively adjust the d-band center and electronic structure of Ru active sites, thus improving the OER performance of ruthenium oxides [ 227 ]. It was demonstrated that Cr doping enhanced the electrical conductivity of nanoneedles (NNS) and the active sites on NNS, significantly improving the HER and OER activities. Liu et al. [ 275 ] synthesized amorphous Cr-doped NiCo2O4 (Cr-NiCo2O4) NNSs grown in NF as both the cathode and anode of overall water splitting. The NNS structure provides a large surface area, and the distal part of the NNS has more active centers due to the high conductivity of Cr-NiCo2O4 itself (Figs. 29(a) and 29(c) ). The catalyst reached the current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 under low potentials of 1.53 and 1.65 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH (Fig. 29(b)) [ 275 ]. The two-dimensional structure can expose more active sites while providing a larger surface area, which is beneficial for improving the OWS performance of electrocatalysts. Yao et al. [ 234 ] synthesized channel-rich amorphous RuCu snowflake-like nanosheets (NSs) using the one-pot method using crystalline Ru and amorphous Cu. Based on the obtained electrochemical data, minimization of Coulomb repulsion and mitigation of t2g-eg splitting on the catalyst surface were attributed to highly electroactive channel structures and further demonstrated by DFT. The RuCu NSs/C reached 10 mA cm−2 at cell voltages of only 1.49, 1.55, 1.49 and 1.50 V in 1 mol L−1 KOH, 0.1 mol L−1 KOH, 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 and 0.05 mol L−1 H2SO4, respectively (Figs. 29(d)–(g)) [ 234 ]. Adding Cu2+ is the key to forming higher electrocatalytic activity for amorphous CoMoO3 and nanostructures. For example, introducing Cu2+ into CoMoO3 to form amorphous CoMoO3/Cu (a-CoMoO3/Cu) electrodes can trigger the formation of highly reactive a-CoMoO3 and conductive Cu by hindering the precipitation of Co-Mo alloys, facilitating the exposure of active sites and then enhancing the electrochemical catalytic activity [ 276 ]. Subsequently, we have summarized the development of OWS electrocatalysts (Fig. 30 ). Alkaline electrolyzers are a proven technology that can be used for large-scale hydrogen production, and the catalysts with excellent HER/OER performance alone have been explored extensively, but when two catalysts are paired in the same electrolyzer, good electrolytic water results are generally not achieved due to combined electrolytic incompatibility. Especially at high currents, the catalysts are corroded severely, leading to performance degradation. Amorphous catalysts with structural flexibility attributes can self-adjust according to catalytic conditions and provide active sites from multiple dimensions, thus reducing performance degradation. Currently, most amorphous bifunctional materials are monometallic, and developing amorphous bifunctional catalysts with multiple elemental compositions remains challenging. 5.4 In-situ characterization and density functional calculations Compared with traditional ex-situ characterization methods, in-situ characterization can detect the real-time changes in structure, chemical state, and coordination atoms of materials, which facilitates the precise understanding of catalyst structure and the following construction of theoretical models. At this stage, the application of in-situ XRD, in-situ Raman, in-situ TEM, in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and other testing means in amorphous water splitting catalysts has made excellent contributions to the interpretation of catalytic mechanism and further improvement of catalyst performance. The in-situ XRD is used to determine the structural changes of the amorphous catalysts during water splitting. Bergmann et al. explained the structural similarities and differences of the active sites for crystalline and amorphous catalysts by using in-situ XRD and pointed out that the amorphous shell with catalytic activity can be formed on the crystalline oxide during OER and transforms into a more stable crystalline state when the OER ends. In-situ XAS can obtain the oxidation states, electronic structure, and local coordination environment of catalysts during electrocatalysis, from the bulk to the nanoscale, and even a single atom [ 277 ] Liu et al. [ 278 ] combined in-situ XAS, in-situ X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) and first-principle calculations to demonstrate that the ultrathin, amorphous and alloyed states can be easily transformed into active phases, thus significantly increasing the catalytic activity. The in-situ characterizations provide an important theoretical basis for the preparation of advanced catalysts by explaining the mechanism of active phase formation during the reaction process. We generally believe that the electrochemical reactions occur at the catalyst surface, so surface structure deeply influences catalyst performance. In-situ Raman can detect changes at the electrode-electrolyte interface, helping to enhance the understanding of the catalytic mechanism. Deng et al. [ 279 ] used in-situ Raman and other characterization tests to reveal the real active site of Ni9S8 during OER. They found that during electrochemical activation, Ni9S8 can form amorphous nickel oxide, which is eventually converted to NiOOH after partial loss of sulfur. Jia et al. [ 280 ] obtained amorphous FeOOH doped with Mo by a reconfiguration strategy. By In-situ Raman, they found that MoS2/FeC2O4 formed two broad peaks corresponding to transition metal hydroxides at 439 and 474 cm−1 (Figs. 31(a) and 31(b) ), which was transformed into MoFeOOH during the electrochemical process and served as the active species. The above in-situ techniques are useful for detecting structural and electronic changes during electrocatalysis but can not provide corresponding information on morphological changes. The application of in-situ TEM can provide insights into catalyst morphology and structure at the atomic or nanoscale during electrocatalytic reactions. Peña et al. [ 281 ] used in-situ TEM to study the morphological and structural evolution of Co3O4 nanoparticles during OER, and they found that the surface of Co3O4 underwent irreversible amorphization. It was also reported that the amorphous CoS x can be transformed into crystalline CoOOH with the help of in-situ TEM during the OER, as it served as the real active species [ 282 ]. Unfortunately, the amorphous catalysts may have multiple reaction processes, it is still difficult to precisely analyze the surface active sites, and the available atomic-scale resolution is still insufficient for detecting most actual catalysts. First-principle calculations, which are connected closely with the in-situ techniques, are an effective method to predict the performance of electrochemical catalysts. However, the difficulty of modeling amorphous materials and the huge cost of DFT calculations lead to the relationship between the performance of amorphous catalysts and the local atomic environment remaining unknown. Machine learning (ML) is emerging as an ideal complementary means to combine specific data sets with specialized knowledge to obtain information in the shortest time [ 283 ]. The combination of ML methods and traditional calculations has been successfully applied in the design of electrocatalysis and is also a reliable method for studying the effects of local atomic environments in amorphous alloys. A Smooth Overlap of Atomic Positions-Machine learning (SOAP-ML) model was developed by Gao et al. [ 284 ] and combined with DFT calculations, they successfully predicted the catalytic effect of the local atomic environment (Fig. 31(c)). They calculated 40000 active sites on the surface of amorphous alloy to obtain the optimal Cu-Ni ratio and found that the long cycle life of amorphous alloy was related to the Ni dealloying, consistent with the experimental results. The expanding lattice method is also frequently used in DFT calculations for model construction of amorphous materials. The principle is constructing a crystalline super-monomer that relaxes its internal structure by reducing the density and doubling the volume to form a low-density disordered structure. Thenuwara et al. [ 285 ] used the expanding lattice method to construct an amorphous Co-Mo-P model and simulated the energetics of HER intermediates using DFT calculations. However, the construction method of the above model is not applicable to the construction of crystalline/amorphous interfaces (CAI) in the DFT calculation. Gu et al. [ 286 ] combined DFT calculations and ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) to construct the CAI model. By preparing a trimetallic FeCo(NiS2)4 catalyst with numerous CAI (FeCo(NiS2)4-C/A), it was demonstrated that the Co contained in the CAI can promote both HER and OER, which remedies the lack of theoretical studies on the role of CAI in the water splitting process. 5.5 Modification strategies for amorphous electrocatalysts Besides the above-mentioned amorphous water decomposition electrocatalysts, amorphous single-atom or diatomic catalysts, amorphous 2D layered materials, amorphous single-atom-layer and other amorphous materials with special, modified structures have also received significant attention. Single-atom catalysts are rapidly becoming a research frontier in the field of catalysis due to their excellent atom utilization and unique size quantum effects [ 287,288 ]. In single-atom catalysts, the atomic configuration of the carrier plays an important role in enhancing the catalytic activity of extrinsic single atoms. Compared to crystalline structures, amorphous structures can generate abundant metal dangling bonds with flexibly unsaturated electronic configurations, accelerating the charge transfer between active sites. The use of amorphous materials as carriers in the construction of single-atom/diatomic catalysts can induce orbital coupling and promote electron transfer to further optimize the electronic structure of catalysts and thus enhance their performance [ 289 ]. With the further reduction of catalyst size [ 290 ], the monolayer thickness of noble metal atoms is near the limit (for thickness of ~1 nm), that is, single-atom layer catalysts. In 2D single-atom layer catalysts, nearly all atoms can be tuned to the maximum density, and the catalytic reactions can occur simultaneously. Meanwhile, their excellent electrocatalytic activity and stable thermodynamics greatly increase their application in various electrocatalytic reactions. He et al. [ 291 ] prepared amorphous PtSe x layers with a thickness of about 1 nm using the strategy of low-temperature processing and the low-density Ar plasma, which can remain thermodynamically stable in a two-dimensional form. The ultrathin amorphous layer with high stability can expose almost all Pt species during the electrochemical reaction. Beyond the PtSe x layer materials, PdSe x , IrSe x , OsSe x , RuSe x , and RhSe x can also serve as amorphous selenides to design noble metal single-atom layer catalysts with enhanced catalytic activity. 6 Conclusions and perspectives This study reviews the latest progress of amorphous electrocatalysts toward HER, OER, and OWS, and the corresponding mechanisms are also investigated. Meanwhile, the design strategies and synthesis methods of various amorphous electrocatalysts are presented, as well as the sources of activity and stability enhancement of amorphous catalysts. The advantages and disadvantages of each synthesis method are compared carefully. Besides, the applications of amorphous catalysts, including precious-metal-based, Ni-based, Mo-based, Fe-based, Co-based, and so on, are highlighted, and insights for future research on water splitting are provided. The water-splitting ability of the aforementioned amorphous catalysts, including precious metals and transition metals, has been generally enhanced compared with the corresponding conventional crystalline catalysts. 6.1 The existing science challenges Despite the above advancements, significant challenges regarding the amorphous electrocatalysts remain. They include: (1) The low electrical conductivity. The amorphous materials usually show poor conductivity owing to the intrinsic long-range disorder, which hinders electron transfer. Thus, increasing the conductivity of amorphous catalysts for electrically induced chemical reactions is necessary. (2) The unsatisfactory stability, especially at high current densities. During the electrochemical process, some sites of amorphous materials are easily attacked by water or ions, leading to the degradation of the catalyst by corrosion. Adjusting the geometric configuration makes it possible to change the attacked sites of amorphous electrocatalysts and improve their corrosion resistance. (3) The difficult accessibility for some amorphous materials. Amorphous nanomaterials tend to crystallize at high temperatures and under harsh conditions due to their thermal instability. Their chemical synthesis and accurate control of morphology remain a great challenge. (4) The in-depth catalytic mechanism understanding of the amorphous electrocatalyst. The arrangement of atoms in amorphous materials is quite complex and remains unclear in electrochemical reactions. Thus, figuring out the specific structure, coordination information, and active sites is difficult. (5) Industrial prospects. Presently, most of the prepared amorphous electrocatalysts are still far from industrial production requirements in terms of catalytic performance and stability. Compared with the Ni-based water cracking catalysts currently used in industry, there is a need to reduce the cost and improve the versatility, superhydrophilicity, and corrosion resistance of amorphous electrocatalysts at a later stage. 6.2 The appealing directions for the future Based on the above discussions on the current challenges, the following research is proposed: (1) Introduction of conductive materials. The poor conductivity of metal-based catalysts in the amorphous phase can be alleviated by adding conductive substances and constructing special conductive structures. The core-shell layer nanostructures are a promising solution, where the synergistic effect between the core and the shell layer can modulate the electronic structure and promote the electron transfer from the core to the shell layer. For example, recent DFT calculations have shown that Fe can induce electron transfer from Fe to Ni in the Ni-Fe center, increasing the carrier density and improving the conductivity. Introducing conductive materials such as graphene in amorphous electrocatalysts is also beneficial to improve the weak conductivity of the materials. Besides, using self-supporting substrates (Cu foam, Ni foam, etc.) is a promising future strategy to synthesize amorphous catalysts with higher conductivity and larger active areas. (2) Novel synthesis strategies. Compared with the crystalline state, the composition and morphology of amorphous materials are still less studied, and the preparation of amorphous materials remains challenging due to the strong intermolecular metal bonds. By forming a thin active amorphous layer on the surface of the electrocatalyst, it is possible to exploit the structural flexibility of amorphous materials while making their preparation simpler. Integrating amorphous structures, amorphous surface coating, construction of crystal-amorphous heterostructures, and anionic defects into ultrathin two-dimensional materials are effective methods for improving catalytic efficiency. (3) The application of a highly adjustable structure. The metastable and flexible structure characteristics endow amorphous materials with a higher adjustability compared to crystalline materials. On the one hand, the flexibility of amorphous materials can make the active sites easily adopt any geometry required during electrocatalysis. On the other hand, amorphous materials could easily reassemble to form any type of crystalline counterpart for enhancing the activity. (4) The advanced characterization tools. Combining experimental results and advanced characterization tools to understand the underlying mechanism is essential and feasible. In addition to the conventional Raman, STEM, and XPS, the combination of more precise and accurate characterization tools such as nanobeam electron diffraction (NBED), nuclear reaction analysis (NRA), and X-ray absorption fine spectrum (XAFS) is beneficial to the understanding of amorphous electrocatalysts. (5) Using theory calculations. Considering the difficulty of modeling amorphous materials and the still-unknown relationship between the performance of amorphous catalysts and the local atomic environment, more theory calculations combining novel Machine Learning and Material Genome should be widely applied to predict and construct new amorphous structures accompanying high electrocatalytic activity in water splitting. (6) Scope of application. By enhancing the stability of amorphous electrocatalysts, they can be used in extreme environments, such as high temperature, low temperature, wide pH range, irradiation, and seawater. Studying the amorphous geometry and active sites can enable the prediction of the electrolyte attack site during water splitting, consequently extending the service life of amorphous electrocatalysts. Besides, the amorphous electrocatalysts can be further developed for use in much-broadened applications, such as glycerol oxidation, methane oxidation, and so on. With further research, these issues are expected to be resolved. Hopefully, this review could help readers figure out a clear picture of the current research status of amorphous materials as a promising HER/OER/OWS catalyst and in understanding the role, performance, and challenges of amorphous catalysts in water splitting to obtain more and more opportunities for the future commercial application of amorphous catalysts. Xiangzhi Cui received her Ph.D. degree in 2009 at Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, and has been working at the institute since then. Now she is a full professor of the Institute. Her main research interest includes the structural design and synthesis of nanostructured composites, and the electrochemical catalysis for clean energy. Han Tian received his Ph.D. degree in 2021 at Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, and has been working as a postdoctor at the institute since then. His main research interest includes the structural design and synthesis of nanostructured composites in water splitting and proton exchange membrane fuel cells.

coredata.dc:description: Amorphous materials can markedly enhance the active site amount and optimize the adsorption and desorption of reactants owing to the special structural characteristics of large numbers of randomly oriented bonds and surface-exposed defects. Therefore, many amorphous electrocatalysts have emerged for effectively catalyzing water splitting. Considering the advancement of novel in-situ techniques and theoretical density functional theory calculations, significant progress emerging in amorphous electrocatalysts for water splitting needs to be summarized urgently. Herein, the recent progress of amorphous catalyst materials in water splitting has been systematically reviewed, emphasizing key issues of synthesis methods, stabilization strategies, performance evaluation, mechanistic understanding, integrated experiments, and theoretical studies in water splitting, including hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, and overall water splitting. This study focuses on these topics to present the most updated results and the perspectives and challenges for the future development of amorphous electrocatalysts toward water splitting.

coredata.dc:title: Advances and insights in amorphous electrocatalyst towards water splitting
